reviewText:
By far, one of the best, most interesting games I've played. I've never been too fond of the horror genre yet I was able to complete this game in an exciting 25 hours.
This game is very much related to the films, you play as Amanda Ripley (Ellen Ripley's daughter). You start off on The Torrens. After finding out that a flight recorder left by Amanda's mum is on another ship nearby called Sevastapol, Amanda feels the need to find out what happened to her.
Ellen Ripley was on a ship called the Nostromo years ago, and Amanda's 'space buddies' join her to find out about the ship, presumably knowing that there was an unknown species (duh alien) on the Nostromo.
Unsuprisingly, you find out that there are aliens breeding and feeding on Sevestapol.

Throughout the game you continuously complete intense missions, helping you find out more and more about Amanda's mum, yet somehow it quickly turns into a survival/stealth game in which you attempt to stop the 'one' alien.
This game heavily requires patience as you stealth past androids, armed humans and the alien.

I give this game a solid 9/10 due to its beautiful graphics, atmosphere and ablility to make a game interesting and fun for a whole 20 hours at least.
The remaining 10% goes to the game becoming slightly predictable and the occasional glitch of an alien seeing you when it shouldn't kind of thing.

If anyone asks me to recommend them a game, I would most definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
The scariest game out now.

This is the best game made for the IP, certainly, but that's almost damning the title with faint praise. What it really is, is the most accomplished and sophisticated of the first person horror games released so far.

I'm a big fan of Penumbra: Overture and Black Plague, I very much enjoyed Amnesia too. They came along when first person and adventure games were becoming quite stale, so I'll always be very fond of them. I played them with relish and love them for incepting a whole genre, essentially. But they were far from flawless. Likewise the Bioshock franchise, which has many positive qualities, also lacks somewhat. It fails to recreate the sense of tension System Shock 2 had, and it also fails to create a realistic sense of place in its game levels. Atmospheric as Rapture is, it only vaguely felt like a city, and much more specifically like a dungeon for you to kill people in.

The reason these games are relevant to this review is because Alien: Isolation recreates them mechanically almost blow for blow. A crafting system not unlike that found in Bioshock exists here, but it's far stripped back, Being lean and always useful but never overpowering you or giving you a too great sense of confidence, in contrast to Bioshocks items and abilities systems which always were, quite frankly, bloated. I initially ignored the system, as I do most crafting systems, be cause they usually ARE ignorable distractions from playing the main game. But here, medpacks, molotovs, noisemakers and all kinds of other junk you can make save you a world of trouble, and you quickly learn to pay attention to the little side areas that contain treasure troves of crafting materials and ammo.

Further, Alien: Isolation is imbued with an aesthetic sense far finer than its inspirations. Dialogue and story, especially at the crucial opening act of the game, are subtle, well measured, realistic and feel quite human. Most commendable is Amanda Ripley herself, who functions perfectly as the voice of the player. She never just accepts the bizarrely violent  world on board the station as the half-mute protagonists of Bioshock usually do, and demands explanations from word go. Such a feature is crucial because it allows the player to accept the in-universe situation as an emotional one, not just one with mechanical obstacles and story as pretense for it.

This subtle, detail oriented mentality extends to the visuals of the game. Art direction is not just slavishly devoted to the design patterns used for the environments in the original Alien, but also to creating a sense of humanity. Environments are scaled to human use, stuffed with normal human rubbish (candy bars, cokes, pens, papers, the fodder of workstations) and their layouts are logical in the sense of their utility first (a medical centre is planned out just like a medical centre should be), not in the service of gameplay, a mistake both Bioshock and the Frictional games make.

And that's the secret to Alien: Isolation. I enjoyed this game immensely. Not because it showed me something new, but because it showed how taking something that's already popular and done well, then adding the extra 10% of love and thought, creates much more than just 10% more fun, it can give a game a reason to be remembered for being more than just the best of the three good games amongst dozens of mediocrity that were produced for X movie franchise"."

reviewText:
A well deserved love letter to the series and one of the greatest works to come out of the franchise. As a fan of the first two Alien films, this game was amazing to play.

+Recreates the setting of the first film to a tee.
+Challenging survival horror stealth gameplay (best played on Hard, trust me)
+Surprisingly smart alien A.I. that adapts to your playstyle
+Scary without relying on jump scares like so many others in the genre. Fear is built up naturally and the constant threat of the alien builds great tension.
+Well paced, with down time to break up the alien parts
+Working Joes are an interesting take on Alien synthetics and deserve to be canon
+Graphically stunning. Lighting is amazing.
+Sound design is some of the best I’ve experienced. Headphones are a must.
+Amazing fan service (not the XXX kind), one scene in particular being breathtaking
+Long campaign that gives your money’s worth (almost 30 hours on hardest difficulty)
+DLC is good and fair
-Story is not its strong point.
-Anti-aliasing is pretty bad for some reason
-Some deaths were predictable. Even though it’s an Alien game, too many people died.
-Flamethrower felt overpowered towards the end as ammo was too common
-Horribly unsatisfying ending

Have you ever wondered what it would be like to be on a spaceship and hide from a xenomorph? Well, Alien: Isolation serves as the perfect simulator for that. I was very hyped for this game when it came out and I am so thankful that Isolation delivered. This game is perfect for me as I love both stealth games and the Alien series. Contrasting from most modern AAA games, Isolation refuses any handholding and instead requires you to learn on your own. One of my most memorable moments was when I sat in a locker with my motion tracker out, hiding from the Xenomorph. It walked in front of the locker, then suddenly pried open the door and devoured me. At that moment I realized that the xeno could hear the tracker, and I ended up relying on the tracker far less throughout the game, to a point where it almost felt as a burden to pull out that beeping machine. As someone who is often cynical towards things that claim to be “scary”, I can honestly that Alien: Isolation is definitely scary. This is no mainstream pretender like Slender or Paranormal Activity, this is legitimately scary. Isolation is a kind of stealth game where you are almost never safe. In the early game, I relied heavily on moving through vents because, foolishly, I thought it was safe. The A.I. must have picked up on this as it started to check by vents more frequently. Eventually it started moving in the vents itself, and hearing those footsteps while in those cramped metal pathways was horrifying. Unlike so many other stealth titles where enemies feel preprogrammed, the xenomorph in Isolation feels like a living breathing enemy out to get you. Its paths don’t feel scripted but also don’t feel random, making all of its movements seem like they have purpose, and that purpose is obvious. It truly feels like it is out to get you, as opposed to the standard stealth foe that walks in distinct lines and has obvious cones of vision. If you’re into that kind of thing, Isolation offers the average stealth gameplay through the Working Joes, robots that are going haywire System Shock style and are also out to get you. I liked the addition of these as it kept the game feeling familiar and gave a good change of pace from the difficult xenomorph sections. Even with all that stealth, Isolation understands that hiding from enemies can be tiresome, so there are down time sections where you simply walk around to do basic tasks. That may seem boring but it actually functions as a good refresher so that the game isn’t just all tension all the time. With all of my compliments to Isolation’s gameplay and horror, I do have gripes with its story. Amanda Ripley is a great character in her own right, and any concerns of her being a lazy ripoff of Ellen were thrown away. However, her relationships with her teammates are not explored much and frankly most of the people outside of Amanda feel boring. When a key person dies and I don’t feel much, then you know your game did a poor job at creating characters. My greatest complaint goes towards the game’s ending. If you know Alien lore, then you know what happens to Ellen (go rewatch Aliens if you want to know). After the many hours I put into getting away from the xenomorph, I was hoping to finally find some peace and quiet for Ellen Ripley, but unfortunately the game gives us a somewhat ambiguous and unsatisfying ending to such a long story. There lies another issue: the game felt too long. I know, that might sound strange in a medium where games are often scolded for being too short. Isolation on the other hand is one of the few examples of games that dragged on too long. The story is filled with many “oh wait” moments, where you think your struggle against the xeno is finished only to find that it is still a threat. While this is in line with the franchise’s fashion, it can get tiresome especially with how long the game turned out to be. While I prefer a game to be too long than too short, the Isolation developers tried a bit too hard in putting things into their game. I appreciate the efforts they put into making this game but they did overdo themselves a bit.

Wow, this turned out to be a pretty lengthy review but that's because I have so much to say about this wonderful game. At the end of the day, this is a game that was evidently made by Alien fans for Alien fans. Even if you aren’t big on the franchise, buy this game if you enjoy stealth gameplay or are just wanting a good scare.

reviewText:
I honestly can't believe how much I find myself intrigued by this game. Truthfully, it recreates the 1979 Alien scenery beautifully and the developers also wraps this gorgeous lollipop with another sugar coating just to make sure, by having some great, innovative and fun elements.
The first few things that I noticed instantly that I absolutely adored:
The environment, the overall high-quality textures and the precise attention-to-detail. There are so many things that makes you believe that you're back in time. I know I was born 1996 and therefore cannot know how it exactly was back then, but judging by the movies and pictures, it's kind of obvious to me that Creative Assembly indeed did their homework here. They made me wanting to explore Sevastopol, they make me want to go through the story and listen to the Archive Logs, Nostromo Logs, etc. Well worth a strong 9/10 in this department

The feeling of fear and despair. What I noticed after playing through this game was that the Xenomorph truly is invincible. The question ultimately lands on one's hands, asking whether or not you're willing to pay the ultimate price to defeat God. Speaking of an ultimate price, I want to have a say about the ending in this review, and I'll come to this opinion later on. With this point - to sum it up - I was trying to get across to you of the feelings you get when playing this game. You will fear enemies (esp. the Alien itself) and you will need to change pants after a session of Alien: Isolation"

reviewText:
A crawl-on-your-stomach simulator and coincidentally also one of the best stealth games I ever played. Most never games allow an option of stealth but once discovered the protagonist is usually perfectly capable of getting out of the situation unscattered. Here being found means death. Sure you can postpone it a bit but in the end you have nothing at your disposal that allows you to stop your aggressor for longer than a few minutes.

I recommend this to Alien fans especially (the game respects the lore) and to people who enjoy a challenge. Amanda Ripley is not here to fight a good fight, she is outnumbered, outgunned and unmatched and the longer she stays in once place, the easier it is to find her. Enjoy your stay in Sevastopol.

P.S. Play it on hard" it is worth it. The enemies are much more aware of what is going on which creates a great atmosphere of dread.

P.S. 2 "Don't run

reviewText:
Alien: Isolation puts the player in the shoes of Amanda Ripley, daughter of Ellen Ripley, seeking information about her Mother's disappearance fifteen years after the events of the first film.

Isolation is one of the most well-optimised games I've ever had the joy of playing, it runs on almost max settings on my AMD Radeon R7 200, looking utterly beautiful. Rather than modernising the setting, Isolation takes the player back to that late-70s early-80s Scifi setting with fantastic attention to detail. Everything looks utterly faithful to the source material and on the whole the environments are very engaging, encouraging exploration and immersion.

Sound is also fantastic in this game, especially the sound effects. Every single sound you hear is great and couldn't really be done any better in this setting. Audio factors into gameplay, with subtle audio cues betraying the presence of an enemy. The sound and music really helps the immersion, especially when you consider how great the voice acting is too. The sound and the graphics make Isolation one immersive and atmospheric game.

The gameplay of Isolation is comparable to the Penumbra series, asking the player to navigate various environments solving all kinds of objectives whilst avoiding death from some various hazards and opponents. True to the name, Alien: Isolation features a single Xenomorph and it is utterly unkillable. The player can craft or find some distractions and even weapons, but flames and bullets will only scare your fearsome foe away temporarily. The alien will return. It always returns! Like most horror games the experience is much more tense if the fear of death is heightened, so I highly reccomend players put Isolation on hard difficulty.

Although I haven't beaten the game yet, reviewers claim the game is very long with IGN hilariously claiming it's TOO long. On top of this the game has a 'Survival' mode that puts you in a smaller map with a single objective to be completed against even more difficult enemies. More missions will no doubt be released as DLC.

The Verdict: A fantastic atmospheric horror game and a glorious return to form for Aliens videogames.

reviewText: This game would be fantastic if the studio released a patch for a bug which has been reported by many people over the last 6 months: when you try to access a rewire panel you sometimes get stuck and cannot exit the panel. The workaround *recommended by the studio* on their forums is to reload from a save point (losing big chunks of progress). The fact that a studio would release such an otherwise excellent game and then simply decline to fix a simple but experience-crippling bug is baffling and disappointing. I would love to recommend this game, but I can't.

reviewText:
There are both good and bad things about this game.

Pros: Aliens,  Ellen Ripley's voice	  and good game time
Great story to continue the franchise.
27 hours worth of playtime on medium difficulty, if you creep around slowly and hide in a closet for a hour or two lol.


Cons: Glitches in random places.
From the very begining I experienced a problem with the fuse boxes. I would enter the interface and then after it loaded the screen it wouldn't allow me to reroute the power to other areas. It would get stuck and not allow me to exit the fuse box. I reload and it would happen again so after reloading 3 times I was finally  able to finish messing with the box.

I had problems with the levels loading properly and the only way to fix was by lowering the resolution down to 800x600 and changing the graphics down to low on everything.


Overall experience 8/10

I could give a better review but honestly its a good game but does have some problems that go along with it like most games.

reviewText:
This game was such a breath of fresh air for me. First horror game that I've actually finished. This game shows that it's possible to scare you without using cheap jump scare tactics, but atmosphere. I loved it. To summarize:

+ Attention to detail was amazing!
+ Soundtrack
+ Characters
+ Atmosphere
+ Runs well

- Actions sometimes don't respond, like when trying to climb into a vent. You have to be at a specific distance from the object and look at it the right way. This didn't always happen, but was frustrating at times.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
How to explain this game without giving away spoilers...

A heart pumping adventure that has you building schematics, dodging those who wish to do you harm, dodging an alien that feels like a player, all the while being immersed in an audio soundtrack that just makes things a million times worse for the player when using surround sound.

Having played just a couple hours exploring and being sneaky I had just commented to a friend... Wow... Not even seen an alien yet" and wouldnt you know it... That is when he appears.

Unfolding his sleak frame and appearing to be a true killer you finally get to meet the star of the game.   The AI is exceptional with him reacting to sounds very quickly.  He also likes to stalk you a bit... much the same way a predator in nature would stalk you this AI does the same.   Chosing at times the path you do not really expect him to take and doing so damn fast.

Having a ton of fun and would say that this is definately a MUST HAVE title for any fan of Aliens.

Just make sure you bring a change of underwear."

reviewText: Ridley Scott's 1979 Alien" was one of the first horror movies I ever saw as a kid. I grew up loving the Alien movies and this game was an awesome homage and add on to the story of the original.\nAlthough this game scored higher postive review scores than negative ones
date: I was confused about some of the gamer complaints....."It's too hard. I have to hide all the time. " I'm not sure what mode they played it on
recommended:
but I played it on normal and had a f****** blast! This is by far the best "Alien" game out of the many disasters and the only one people should play.

PROS:
*GORGEOUS graphics and attention to detail (I wondered around for hours just reading posted notes attached to desks)
*Amanda Riply is a fantastic lead character
hoursPlayed:
who for once said MANY of the things I was thinking when I have played similar "fix-and-fetch" quests. For example: "Why is this ship a piece of ♥♥♥♥?" "WHy don't you go fix the power reactor?" "Why are you all so worthless at fixing ANYTHING?!" I chuckled several times.
*The gadgets you can make are pretty cool and not just "balls-to-the-walls" machine guns and grenande launchers. You have to rely on stealth.
*The Working Joe androids were scarier than the Alien itself. The little things they mutter to themselves and to others are f****** creepy.
*The DLC "Crew Expendable" and "Lone Survivor" are great because they allow you to play actual characters from the original Alien story. These are short

but sweet.

The game play is consistent and the story line awesome

reviewText: This game is hands down one of the most scary game I have ever played. an ultimate SIFI horror! Heart pounding! Even before I saw the Alien for the first time, the music score alone had me in a panic thinking the creature was right behind me as I waited for an elevator. And when I finally saw the creature I was wishing to be back on the level before I saw it. Panic would set in as you would hide from this creature as it stalked you. The telltail THUMP! THUMP! THUMP! THUMP! of its footsteps as it roamed the halls looking for its next victim. THAT DARN HISSING AND GROWLING IT WOULD MAKE! And as you hide from it, sometimes with very little cover, your heart will start pumping and that fight or flight feeling will come over you. And then ..... It STOPS RIGHT NEXT TO YOU AS IF TO TURN AND OUNCE ON YOU! and you think it's  GAME OVER MAN GAME OVER! then it walks off.....Leaving you catching your breath. Oh and did I mention I'm not far along in this game? LOL I highly recommend playing this game in the dark by yourself. This game will have you on the edge of your seat and leaning off to one side just to hide a little better from the creature! I would give this game a 5 out of 5 star rating. Good luck and I hope you make it!

reviewText: Absolutely fantastic. Lives up to everything promised. Clearly this team actually does love and cherrish the source material. I have absolutely no regrets about preordering. Only problems were some occasional model clipping, but thats to be expected in any game. The game ran almost perfectly. I did have some crashes and bugs, but that was only related to one specific enemy. I do not wish to say which specific enemy caused these bugs because spoilers, but it wasnt the Xenomorph, Androids, or the Humans. I was quite surprised at the number of weapons in the game, shotgun and pistol to name a few. The Xenomorph is smart and can't die, but on easy difficulty becomes more of a minor inconvience once you get your hand on the flamethrower. I wish I could give it a rating higher than 10/10, but sadly thats impossible, no matter how many other reviewers say 11/10.

reviewText: Gameplay:You may hear about the fact that the second half of the game has some issues"
date: but I did not find this to be as bad as others may lead you to believe.\n\nThe build up to the first enemy encounter is done very well. It doesn't just throw you into the action (which would make you too comfortable with the enemies). Up to Mission 10
recommended: your encounters with the alien will be reminiscent of Amnesia. You won't have very effective deterrents and you will need to hide a lot. Sometimes the Alien will pin down your location and begin to take a relatively repetitive pattern. In these situations you need to use a Pipe Bomb
hoursPlayed: Noisemaker
voteText: Molotov and possibly the Flare to disrupt it and escape.\n\nA lot of the complaints you will hear come from Missions 11 and 12. At this point you will already have the Flamethrower and you will receive an excessive amount of supplies while fighting the relatively easy to beat Working Joes. I don't agree with people's complaints here. These missions make you begin to feel comfortable and make you let your guard down. (Personally
helpfulPercent: I thought it was nice to take a sort of intermission and enjoy the atmosphere for a few levels.) Then in Mission #13 you are thrown into an area with Raincoat Working Joes (invulnerable to everything except the Shotgun and Bolt Gun). This brings the difficulty level back up
votesHelpful: but it's arguably less intense because they do not insta-kill.\n\nFor the last five Missions of the game
votesTotal: you will be thrown back into the intense Alien Survival Horror gameplay
votesFunny: but this time you will really need the items you collected through the last few levels. This last segment of the game is a blend of Survival Horror and Action. It fits well at this point due to the amount of different enemies you have to deal with.\n\nI honestly enjoyed the change of pace after Missions 3 - 10. The Survival Horror style gameplay

reviewText:
**Mild End spoilers**

A masterpiece well crafted with genuine tense and heart pounding moments . Type of game where you eagerly wait for save point and  breathe a sigh of relief . A game where you genuinely want you character to escape . Complains are there for little bit longer campaign and yes fat could have been trimmed from middle game . But last chapters ?  Man those chapters were awesome . Your character is about escape but is pulled down again for one last objective , you are 1 inch closer to your escape but still it looks miles away . You are fighting for every breath and every move you make for  your escape . This really intensified the surival horror element . End chapters were kickass . When you turn on the last generator and the music kicks in , Holy ♥♥♥♥ !! Epic !!

Top notch atmosphere , sound effects , visuals & great alien A.I. , ♥♥♥♥er will test your patience and make you clench your toes  . Play with headphones for full experience .

All in all if you are a survival horror fan then play this gem . Last but not the least ,  just like mother , amanda is a badass & tough soul .

9.5/10

reviewText:
The best Alien game I've ever played, this masterpiece really got the hook on the real nature of the Alien, which is a deadly xenomorph that you can't kill in huge numbers like they were cockroaches. Just one of them is enough to kill hundreds of people which is shown here aswell.
I grew up with Alien movies, so Alien games are something I always buy whenever they get released, and this one didn't disappoint me, but actually surprised me.

It is a horror game in all forms, and you always need to go around scavenging for stuff to survive, building stimpaks etc.
Knowing that an Alien could be in the next room at all times, made me paranoid as hell.
The Aliens animations are very cool aswell, and the stealth gameplay in general is fluid.

It is not like the Amnesia games, because you have the means to destroy other humans and robots in your way, but the Alien itself can only be scared away by a flamethrower or lots of bullets, even then you are not sure if you've done so, it only buys you a few seconds to move further ahead.
Many times when I think the Alien is long gone, then all of a sudden I walk through a door or corridor and then it pounces and strikes me down out of nowhere.

Creative Assembly have done an amazing job with this horror pearl, and they deserve praise for that.

reviewText:
I had a violent first outing with this game that ended with my giving up and quitting for about 5 months. I'm very lucky that I was convinced by a random internet commenter to give it a second chance, and that my white-knuckled, pontificating rage at a particular early level (the Medical Ward) was not an uncommon reaction to that questionably-designed section of the game. The dissatisfaction I felt when I realized your main antagonist, the eponymous alien, is designed to stay within a certain radius of you when you crawl a football field away from it in total silence made me feel smart and sophisticated as a long-time survival horror buff, but when I returned to see the game through, I came to the paradigm-shattering conclusion that sometimes current, and major, design studios can still get things extremely right.

On that first go, I quickly surmised that the plot is mostly phoned-in. And to a degree, I stand by that--the whole thing isn't much more than a sure-to-please rehash of the first Alien movie, but it does serve as a wealth of opportunity to internalize that film's impact by enabling you to live and breathe the carnivorous, soaring agony of having the odds stacked so high against you. Like Ellen Ripley, you might find yourself staring down the acid-drizzling xenomorph in the room, moving as slow as you can to your objective, humming quietly to keep yourself cool. It takes a lot of nerve and a fair bit of cunning to stay alive.

I don't want to get too psychoanalytical when talking about this game (though it does strike me as a powerful duplication of the Silent Hill 3 package--in which a woman has to navigate an openly hostile male-dominated environment and is hunted, relentlessly, by psychosexual terror and betrayed by just about everyone [there, I said it]), but the effort that went into generating this specific flavor of all-out dread is simply marvellous to see these days.

The atmosphere. My god, it's a thing of beauty. I never expected anyone to let me crawl around inside and rewire the hissing, crackling retrofuturist systems of a doomed space colony as envisioned in the late 1970s. Pipes are bursting, analogue computers are clacking and spinning reels of tape, and you can hear the station's skeleton moan as it falls from orbit around a looming gas giant. That vibe trickles all the way down to the oily, decaying, blue-collar details of the hellscape that you traverse, and you get a very tactile feel for these environments and the engineering obstacles you encounter--you click both mouse buttons to clamp onto a bolt with your maintenance jack, then hold down the corresponding WASD key to break the bolt loose. Your security tuner sings a little chiptune melody while it warms up, and you can damn-near feel that the thing is a mostly-hollow hunk of low-memory plastic when you hear its buttons and notched dial click as you hack through a door. I ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ -love- the attention given to the gadgetry.

The gameplay is like a linear Metroid Prime-via-Amnesia-♥♥♥-Bioshock, but the experience borders on exhaustingly tense most of that time thanks to its near-constant cat-and-mouse dynamic. You're being hunted, and you sure don't get a lot of down-time from this anarchic safari. Exploration is encouraged, but only if you've got the stomach to put up with something banging around inside the air ducts above and below nearly every step of the way. I was very happy bypassing most of the collectible lore, and closing those damn elevator doors behind me. Fast.

Despite my grown-up impatience with its overarching familiarity, with its too-rote tropes (psychotic panic-babble scribbled on walls does not interactive storytelling make) and manipulative scripted events, I was able to get absolutely lost in it the further I went. With luck, an emergent gameplay moment will occasionally surpise the ♥♥♥♥ right out of you. Once, while hiding from the alien as it dropped into a hallway outside an operating room, I looked over to find a random NPC crouched behind a turned-over table, shaking and thumbing his revolver, every bit as desperate as I was to stay out of sight. I had a chance to either knock him out and save his life, or keep him conscious to serve as a live distraction so I could slip away. That was when I really learned what this game is, and I felt extremely grateful I had reneged on writing it off.

reviewText:
Alien Isolation is indeed the best Alien video game adaptation out there.
It is long but well paced, and contains so many winks to the movies, and respects the franchise to an amazing degree.

The visuals are simply amazing, I was really impressed multiple times by the smoke particles and the lighting, as well as the level design and how faithful it was to the movie.
Some people have complaints about the game being repetitive, and being about fixing machines and opening doors etc.
But if you take a look at the movies, that is pretty much all they are about too, they make a plan to escape, do some SCI-FI stuff and it usually goes sideways and they need to adapt and make a new plan.

The game is a perfect adaptation of that, and in my opinion it was just the right lentgh.
I enjoyed the Stealth mechanics (played on Hard) and I really enjoyed using the tools that the game gave me to distract/attract the Alien.
I finished the game without killing any humans, I would instead attract Androids/Alien to kill them for me, and that felt very satisfying and cool.

All in all, this is now one of my favorite survival horror games, not because it's scary, but because of how well the world is crafted, and how immersive it feels.

reviewText:
Rating:
4.7 out of 5 facehuggers.

Pros:A must for Alien genre fans
A true scifi/horror that makes you feel every moment.
Excellent addition to the Alien storyline and franchise. I'd go as far as saying this should be canon (maybe not every detail but generally).
Stunningly breathtaking visual scenery and attention to detail by the game artists.
Smart Alien AI that adapts to your gameplay. You have to adapt and change to outsmart it.
Seegson Working Joe's are a brilliant addition to the story and are believable rudimentary androids.
Horrifying footsteps, screeches and noise in the vents really makes you crap your pants.
Long campaign. You get your money's worth.
Cons:Experienced one bugged save file late in the campaign meant I had to restore a previous save. Hopefully not a regular occurrence for others.
Somewhat linear storyline. Although you can choose many different paths/options, the story sticks to a script. It would have been nice to have more control over the story.
Summary:
I completed it on the hard setting and found it challenging but rewarding.
Highly recommended and well worth the spend.

reviewText:
The game is very well made, attention to detail is stunning. I was really surprised that its creators are Creative Assembly that make Total War games. First (?) attempt at stealth horror and such terrific success.

Story, characters, acting, everything is top notch. It's too bad these developers aren't making System Shock 3 right now, they would make a masterpiece. This is basically a System Shock like game, but one of the enemies you encounter is unkillable. Remove this, and you'll get a perfect System Shock sequel, a 'thinking man's shooter' instead of a horror game, like 'Aliens' was an action movie after 'Alien' horror. Anyway, if you like System Shock classics, you'll enjoy this one - loads of hacking, engineering, system overrides, audio logs, androids, complex levels - but with a scary arch-enemy that is almost always on your toes so you have little time to enjoy all this stuff. Oh well.

It is scary, so be prepared. It is even more scary in Stereo 3D, but looks really great. If you have nVidia 3D Vision setup, install the patch from HelixMod website that improves the quality of stereo. And if you play on a passive 3D TV like me, make sure to install the monitor driver ovverride to play in proper 1920x1080x60 mode instead of 24 fps (google 'pasive 3dtv edid override').

This game was made for the sneak around stealthy kind of person. It gets intense when you have to run for your life in this game. I swear my voice went up a couple notches to little girl status when the alien was chasing me. Highly reccommended!

reviewText:
BEST ALIEN GAME EVER!

I am a HUGE Alien fan, and so I was really hesitant to pick up this game in fear that it would disappoint me…. I am VERY GLAD that I chose to give it a chance!

Alien Isolation stays true to the source by capturing and adapting every detail (big and small) from the movie. From the eerie soundtrack and sound effects, down to the 1980s computer terminals. To say that I was impressed by the game’s environment would be an understatement. While the art and sound helps set the right atmosphere, the game also has a wonderful story that made me want to keep playing just to find out what’s going to happen next…. No matter how scared I was, I kept pushing forward.  And on that note, the true icing on the cake is the masterfully terrifying AI that was bestowed on the Alien creature that is hunting you down on the station. It is very unpredictable, to such a degree that I would spend 5-10 minutes hiding in a locker still wondering whether or not it’s safe to come out. I played the game on medium difficulty, I am sure on Hard the AI is even more intense. Definitely adds a whole new level of terror to the horror FPS genre.

In conclusion, if you love nearly flat-lining while playing a video game, Alien Isolation won’t disappoint you. And if you love Alien and you ever wanted to know what it would feel like to try and outsmart a Xenomorph, this game captures that experience wonderfully! I was scared all throughout, and I enjoyed every second of it.

10/10

reviewText: I thought Alien Isolation was a terrifying and particularly palatable slice of the Ridley Scott classic, it has tension and atmosphere in abundance, the visuals capture the low-fi tech of 70's-80's film sets and nail it with som aplom, the pace is good and despite being scraed to death at times I kept finding myself coming back for more. The harder difficulties caused me some problems however, the game could become very difficult at times that forced me to lower the difficulty settings but that in itself isn't a problem, the Alien universe is unforgiving after all. The only aspect I have yet to enjoy is the dlc, I found the idea of having time limits for levels a little irritating, it was stressful enough trying to survive the indiginous population of Sevastropol without the timer causing me extra concern. All in all though I think it's the Alien game that has been long overdue and Sega have gone some way in repairing the damage Aliens Colonial Marines caused. 8/10

reviewText: Review after the first playthrough.\n\nI was pulled into the story right from the beginning. The atmosphere has been masterly crafted to resemble the original Alien movies. The story is well written, save for some tedious bits towards the end (see issues list below). I won't repeat it here as much has been written about it elsewhere already. In general, the story is gripping, understandable and not too convoluted in contrast to too many titles nowadays which try to unnecessarily outsmart the player/viewer. Some twists and turns are there as should, but nothing too wild. Stays within the realm of could happen"

reviewText:
Alien: Isolation is hands down the best Aliens game made and definetly the best recent sci-fi horror game i've played.  Despite some minor frustrations in the beginning with not having any idea where I was supposed to go and a fairly slow plot, the game starts picking up tremendously with the introduction of the Alien about an hour or two in.  The alien is absolutely terrifying and a certain experience with the Alien hive terrified me more than any game has before.


Pros:
- Gorgeous Graphics
- Great Stealth Mechanics
- Interesting craftable items (though I didn't use them that much)
- Interesting and mysterious plot
- Satisfyingly scary
- True to the movie Alien

Cons:
- A few minor glitches (the alien can clip through some things and items can float in the air)
- Really long campaign (took me about 24 hours to complete the game)
- There are a lot of mini-games which I mostly found fun but some were kinda stupid
- Lag (my computer laged slightly during the a fairly short reactor sequence)
- The Androids (Super fricking annoying)

Over all if you're a fan of sci-fi horror, and especialy if you love the Alien series, and can get over the few cons get this game.  I'm not a big fan of survival horror and I still enjoyed this game immensely.  9/10

reviewText:
As a long-time fan of the original film, I can't get enough of this game. Very well done. The lighting and atmospherics are the best I've ever seen in any game.  The Nostromo-based DLCs were a real treat as well.

This game took a universe I've loved for years and let me experience it (virtually) first-hand, complete with all the fear and suspense!

I have very few nitpicks, aside from hoping for improved anti-aliasing in future releases. I personally experienced no bugs or crashes on my PC.

I hope there will be a sequel!

reviewText: After the abomination that was Colonial Marines, thanks Gearbox for that one, I'm really proud of The Creative Assembly for their efforts here, what a game to revitalize Alien. The amount of detail that went into this title is beautiful, they really captured the atmosphere that made Alien what it was in the movies. Toss in the Alien, some low-budget malfunctioning androids and a bunch of edgy civilians, make ammunition and high powered weaponry scarce and you've got some serious challenges ahead of you. The game itself recommends you play on hard and there's a good reason why, it's a survival horror. What you need to bare in mind here is you are mostly helpless and the sooner you realize you're not going to take everyone out head on, the sooner you're going to set yourself up to appreciate every tense moment this game throws at you and there will be alot seeing as the Alien will stalk you through every inch of the Sevastopol station. The way in which TCA made a singular alien such a huge threat this time around was a smart move, you will respect the damn thing. It's agile and incredibly aggressive, the worst thing you can possibly do while navigating is run, it's a death sentence, and just because you hid in a locker or escaped into a vent doesn't mean you're safe. Believe me when I tell you that this ♥♥♥♥er can catch you out ANYWHERE. The game paced itself perfectly, the graphics were amazing, showing off one hell of a lighting system that just made the atmosphere top notch, the music was on que with the movies, just about every aspect of this game was done right and true to the movies. It's a game that deserves the title of best game of 2014, easily.

reviewText:
By far the best alien game I've ever played. Atmospheric, intense, and will scare the living crap out of you! You'll be questioning every step you take, and looking not only behind you at the slightest sound as you creep along, but at every nook and cranny for the alien that hunts you.

PRO'S:
Optimization is fantastic - 60 FPS, Everything Ultra on GTX 770
Storyline is great
Will scare you over and over. The Alien is not the only enemy.
Atmosphere is intense
Constructing items is easy and gives a purpose for exploration to find components
Music is great, intense, and fits perfectly for the environment/action
Graphics are INSANELY good. - Turn film grain down to 60 % instead of 100%.

CON'S:
Easy and Medium difficulty dumbs the alien down - Game recommends HARD
Replayability for main story line might be a one time thing, but there's an entire survival mode and might take a few play through's to see everything.

Note: Play with the lights off for extra scare factor.

reviewText:
Alien in the dark
Oh Can I run any faster
Shi'ttn my pants again
Outstanding game.

It has a very minor issues with pacing, perhaps, but rest assured, entire time you are playing it, you will be on the edge of the seat.

Highly recommend playing it on hard difficulty rather than normal or easy. It will make every level, every encounter feel nerve wracking, alien intelligence and the amount of time it spends hunting you increase with difficulty, which makes you feel alive once you complete the level.

DLC is not worth it, unless you are a real fan of the movies, adds very little to the entertainment value of the game.

reviewText:
Finished Alien: Isolation﻿ after 3 nights in a row.
Gotta say, I really liked the game.

The atmosphere and sounds were made really well, and made it easy to immerse yourself in the world. I also liked how faithful the developers were to the movie itself.
I didn't really feel tired of playing at any point during my ~19 hours of game time, and the alien wasn't annoying at all like some other reviewers have said.
The challenges were quite fun to do, too, although there could've been a slightly bigger variety of ways to accomplish them.

Now, I played on hard, and expected the game to be hard after hearing several people complain about how hard, hard is. That didn't really happen. In fact, it was too easy. The alien was in the vents most of the time in the areas it appeared in, and later on in the game when it appeared way more often, you get to have a flame thrower that makes it almost impossible to get killed by it.
Both of these things combined made the scare factor more dull the further I progressed with the game since I learned the way the AI behaved, and how to beat it rather easily.
The AI could've been a tad smarter too, since for some reason it never checked under the tables or in the closets whenever I hid in them (which was rarely), and most of the time you could still easily evade it by standing between some object and just circling around the object so it couldn't see you.
The humans were also quite dumb. There were several times where instead of warning me, they would just start shooting at me, and at the same time attract the alien.. You would figure they would be smart enough not to do that since they know they need to be quiet..
There were also some sound errors (sound suddenly stopping, or completely changing its effects when crossing a certain invisible line), or random guns floating in the air following my character.
The texture quality could also have been higher since there were several places where it did look quite bad in an otherwise good looking game.

If you're considering buying this game, I would definitely recommend it, even if it is for the atmosphere itself, unless you're a person that is very easily scared and cannot finish the game.
But please, if you do decide to play it, watch the Alien﻿ movie first, if you haven't already.
Oh, and play it during the night, with headphones, and everything that can distract you from the game turned off/made silent to really soak in the atmosphere and immersion.

If you somehow managed to read through all of the incomprehensible mess above, then I applaud you.
I write too much at night.

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥ING ATMOSPHERE FOR DAYS.

I love this game, I give it a solid 9/10. The AI might seem annoying at first, but I really learned to appreciate it.

The graphics are ♥♥♥♥ing crazy, game played smooth and everything was clean. There were many times where I would stop and just stare and the surroundings. The lighting was top notch, really complimented and added to the atmosphere.

The music and sounds were very well done. The voice acting was superb. My favorite was the thumping from the alien crawling along the vents above me.

I finished the game in 18 hours, I'm not sure if this is typical. I do like to explore and really get into the game. But those were 18 hours of bliss... though maybe not the space suit parts. Those parts were honestly kind of boring, however they were short. I also haven't touched the dlc, which I actually want to play.

I got this on sale, but I would've paid full price for this.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Welcome to Sevastopol!
A space station, that had a flurishing economy. Well, it should have had.
But over time you find out, that the station has seen its best times. And now it is sold. Sold to a company, which has of course economic interests. This interest is on the station, and it's not the shops or the people.
While you explore the station, you soon realize there is something wrong. The communication is interrupted, people are hiding and are afraid. People are vanishing, Androids behave strange, the station's main computer locks everthing down... to protect. To protect you? No...

The game is about finding all that out. And it's fun. Enjoy the nice views of inside and outside the station, as the graphics is very nice and shows a lot of passion for details. What you see is very close to the interior of the Nostromo you know from the first Alien movie. The game has so many parallels to the movie, it is awesome to experience those details. Also the sound is great, melody and sound effects... you will recognize them again and again from the movie.

There are gamers, who say the game isn't scary. Well, one the one hand you should let get yourself into the atmosphere of the game, as it is much more fun. On the other hand, even if you get used to the frightning atmosphere, the game will stay thrilling over the whole story. Hiding is key.
And the game is not unfair at any time. You just have to learn to recognize the signs. Listen to the sounds, spot hiding places, cause distraction, trust the motion tracker and the direction to the objective (it is from where you stand, and will lead you around obstacles)... then you always have a chance to survive.

Nevertheless the game is not perfect. It has some issues, like different keybinding than shown on screen (at least in the german version), stepless leaning only possible with controller (I used keyboard and mouse all the time), tracker mislead one or two times (path was on a different level). But these are all minor issues imho. The game is very well playable on PC with keyboard and mouse, the only real negative aspect... it's not available for Linux (yet?) ;)

For fans of the Alien franchise this game is a must have of course. It is quite different to all those shooters. But it is also a recommended game for sci-fi fans, survival-horror fans and fans of games where you must not rush through the levels. Because running will make noise, and noise will reveal your position. There are a lot of different dangers, which are seeking for you.

reviewText: I have played alot of ALIEN based games but this really feels like I'm watching a sequel to the original film. The graphics textures are super realistic if you have a capable vcard and the acting is top notch. Reminds me a bit like DOOM 3 but with better cinematic graphics and no texture popping, artifacts or collision. I would compare them to Final Fantasy: Advent Children x10. The set design is very old-school Alien through out. The music is pretty much the original soundtrack with a few extra jolts put in. I like this game because it makes you think carefully and strategize. I'm playing it on hard so it is more realistic and the items are scarce.\nThe bottom line for me is that I wanted a classic scary ALIEN game and this is played in the dark on a large screen with 3d headphones so I am happy to ♥♥♥♥ my pants.

reviewText:
Overall rating: 7/10

Positive:
Very scary game. The scenery is amazing, good graphics and very detailed. Together with the high guality soundtrack and creepy sound effects it creates a very deep atmosphere. Reminded me alot of the first Dead Space game (but even more scary  - I quess mainly because its first person).
The low-fi sci-fi / retro look is a gift for every fan of the alien movie(s) and done very well, very nice design.
So if you don't have the computer to play on ultra settings, I recommend getting it for consoles. During the cutscenes it felt like watching an ALIEN movie.
When combining stealth and action tactics, its very intense. For example I used stealth to bypass an human patrol and reach an generator. Once I pushed the button, I ran away from the androids and the alien and then sneaked up to the human patrol blocking the pass to the exit. My motion tracker told me the alien was coming up behind me (because I was sprinting/running away from it) so I decided to use my gun to shoot some crew members (patrol) while the alien would deal with the rest of them as I just ran through guns blazing to get to the exit before the alien catches me - very close but it worked :)
Since they added androids and hostile crew members, the gameplay brings some changes as it would be pretty repetitive with just the alien. (Altho if you want that, I quess you can play the Nostromo DLC)

Negative:
The AI isn't good at all. Human enemies are pretty stupid. I walked up to two guys and hit one with the hammer (loud melee fight) and the other guy standing right in front of that fight (facing the other way) didn't notice anything.
Standing inside of >OPEN< vents, enemies passing by never noticed me so far.

The alien AI seemed pretty random, but not intelligent at all. Like: yes, you don't know what it's gonna do next - BUT not like it will actually do something, that makes sense. More like scripted random, not intelligent random :D
The alien will always be in the area around you. Yes they said that it could smell you and so be on the hunt for you, but that's not true. It's just SCRIPTED to be nearby. Like, even if it's just heading into the opposite direction of yours and you move on, it will suddenly be teleported into an vent exit nearby. So it's not hunting, just being teleported nearby by scripts. It would also often double and triple check a room instead of checking the other surrounding rooms.
So at those parts it turns from being scary to just being annoying - unless you have the flamethrower ;-)

But atleast it's random, so if you can forgive the very basic AI and live with the scripted stuff, it's still a damn good alien game.

reviewText:
I'm not often compelled to write reviews for games I play, even ones I greatly enjoy... but this game was truly something. I completed it in two sittings.

It took me a few attempts to figure out how things worked in the game, especially line of sight and sound. Once you understand how the different enemy types react to specific stimuli, it becomes rather easy, at least on Medium difficulty. However, this is one of those Metroidvania FPS games where you revisit certain locations of the game multiple times with new tools--and I LOVE that.

This game nails the atmosphere. Sound effects, music, voice acting--all stellar. I highly recommend using surround sound, even if it's virtual.

There are some trial and error moments in the game, but they are few and far between. Those usually set you back a few minutes and can cause some frustration, but it's as simple as learning basic traversal patterns.

As a horror game, this is one of the best. Nothing comes quite close to holding your breath in a locker while the Alien stares into it, or hiding under a table as its tail slithers by. And nothing is quite as heart-pounding as hearing it scream as it spots you, and you make a mad dash around corners looking for a hiding spot. WHEW!

There are set pieces which made me pause and take numerous screenshots. This is a work of art! I will one day (maybe soon) go back into it and play on Nightmare difficulty, but because this game is so long (around 20 hours if you take your time and explore and find collectibles), it may have to wait a bit.

PLAY THIS GAME!

reviewText:
In my opinion. Game Of The Year 2014! :)

Pros:- In all gameplay areas is on a good level of quality (Stealth improving the feeling from games like Outlast, very subtle but tense action, the crafting system similar to games likes The Last of Us and the backtracking, wich is not boring at all).
- The game lenght (19 missions = almost 26 hours in Survivor" mode)
- You get some weapons but you're not overpowered at all.
- The distribution of enemies and kind of moments during the playthrough. You're always anticipating what's next to deal and getting your mind prepared for a different approach.
- Is related to the Alien (1979) xeno-universe.
- A very optimized in-house engine by the people of The Creative Assembly. Is not perfect but I think it makes a great role on all platforms (including last gen). In this PC version DOF
recommended: ambient occlusion and SSS nice. Particles sprites and bakes looks really nice. Every room or moments deserves an screenshot.\n- The art
hoursPlayed: the layout they took from original Nostromo and the lighting and feeling of environments. Is not that oppened but is a little step from other too linear games.\n- Sound design
voteText: folley and the London Philharmonic Orchestra.\n- Related with the folley
helpfulPercent:
the Alien AI is most of the time interesting and feels different each time.
- The variety of mini puzzles
- The scary door haha!
- SPOILER: The Nest!
- Amanda Ripley's voice acting
- Play it with DualShock 4 was great. Most of the actions feels better like the DOF control with one trigger and watching on the corners.
- And of course. The hardest mode. I almost go back to normal but finally I beat the game slowly. It's very rewarding.

Cons:- I wish we could see more NPC's and side quest during the game.
- Some little pop-up assets between a final and a low poly mesh.
- The in-house engine works great but Nostromo outside looks bad.
- Some rigged characters looks robotic.
- The FMV use in some parts of the game.
- The face hugger death animation ¬¬ (the cheapest animation in 2014)
- SPOILER: Samuels artificial life end's too soon :(
- We have to wait for a second part ;)

Recommendations:- Use good headsets ;)
- Use Dualshock 4 or an Xbox Controller (is not an FPS)
- DON'T EVER RUN!
- Learn to craft wisely...some items are not that usefull if you're in a humans / alien / working joe's area.
- RUN! Against working joes if you get discovered use an EMP Mine or an Stunt Baston and just run! (I don't know how difficult is to kill one in normal but in the "Survival" is a pain the A*s).
- Flares can be useful. And there's a lot of them.
- Enjoy the tapes ;) (all of them!)
- Enjoy the music boomboxes like you enjoyed the rest room in Resident Evil games haha!
- Keep moving. AI (most of the time) don't let you be that passive.

Alien Isolation es a great game that we didn't expect after the fiasco of Colonial Marines. It's great that games like Amnesia

reviewText:
I've never seen an Alien movie (on the to do list now). I've never known what this franchise was, what the culture was behind it, and I had never even come close to having a peaking interest in the Alien universe. This fiendishly addictive hellhole of a game has shown me how wrong I was in not looking into the series.

Step into the shoes of Ripley. Amanda Ripley. Struggle onward against seemingly impossible odds, and if you're anything like me, you'll almost feel as though you ARE Ripley. With a relatively slow paced style of play, along with a hearty helping of Storyline, You will step into Sevestopol station. As you traverse this wreckage of something that once was, your goal becomes clear. Survive.

Probably the most thrilling aspect of this game is that if it catches hold of you, which it certainly should, All of Amandas feats and Failures will feel connected to you. as if you'd been there the whole time, catching breaths to avoid detection, frantically searching for a clue as to where it might be. And all of Amandas Failures, will be yours too. her feelings, her thoughts, everything feels as though you, are the one going through the incident. Every emergency station you succesfully trigger will be a wonderful accomplishment, and Amandas yearning to figure out the whereabouts of Ellen Ripley drives you forward.

For newcomers, the story doesn't feel as though you need to see the movie. everything is very nice and clean. It's obvious that Amanda, nor anyone else has encountered anything going on. So don't feel out of the loop if you haven't either (i.e me). With all of this said, take notice that this isn't like more modern games. checkpoints, ammo, and survivablity chances are all heavily in the hands of the player. you won't progress unless you make an effort to do so, and if you don't, you'll die trying.

Although end" is a little lengthy
date: this title is absolutely worth the time. The retro sci-fi enviornment is wonderfully crafted
recommended: and brought back memories of another title held high by myself and others
hoursPlayed: Bioshock.\n\nIn short

reviewText:
All have been said about this game, but I'll throw my 2 cents:

First, it is GORGEOUS. From the scenery to the alien's animation, its almost perfect. The mix between Sci-Fi and 80's tech make everything look functionnal, and effects like fire or water are great. Oh and the sound design may be the best I have seen (or rather heard) in a game to this day.

Second, it is damn TENSE! Not terrifying, but I still had a few jumpscares, and they were NOT SCRIPTED. You really feel like the beast is chasing you, and every move you make can alert it. The progression through the levels is also very well done. The parts where you have to avoid androids can be a bit annoying though.

Finally, the story is cool. You quicky empathize with Amanda, trying to find closure" about her mother's disappearance. All the franchise themes (inhumane corporations

reviewText: This game's attention to detail is insane. I hesitated for a long time to buy this for fear it would be another colonial marines joke. But this game is a true aliens game. The story is great, the voice acting is very well done, the gameplay itself is terrifying and unforgiving, the graphics and design choices are next to perfect.\n\nNow if only we could get a predator game with as much love, then I'd truly be satisfied. If you like aliens, and you like the survival horror genre, this game is about as good as you will ever get.

reviewText:
Get this game. It's incredible. Even though I think the ending and final 2 hours were a bit lackluster, the rest of the game more than makes up for it. The music is great, the graphics are very good, and it's also a great PC port. The story is good as a standalone game for players who don't know alot about the Alien franchise, but it's even better for fans of it, as it's filled with references and audio logs recorded by the original cast of Alien.

I beat the game at hard difficulty, which I recommend. It's a great challenge and I got a bit frustrated at times but I never wanted to lower the difficulty.

The thing I love most about this game is how unscripted the encounters are and how much cool stuff can happen. Some of the best parts of the game is when human enemies are in the same area as the alien and the alien is hunting you both. You do things like purposefully get the other humans to see you so that they will start shooting, so that the alien will hear the gunfire and take them out for you.

Once I was sneaking around this area going into every room scavening for supplies (this game nails survival-horror scavenging and making you feel like every bullet counts) and as I exited the room an enemy human was at the door. I panicked, pulled out my revolver and shot him 2 times in the chest. Knowing the alien heard me, I ran as fast as I could back into the room to hide in a locker. The split second I closed the locker door the alien dropped down from the vent in the ceiling and he eventually wandered away. Moments like this are totally unscripted and they are my favorite part of the game.

This game also has native Oculus Rift support. You have to go into the game's files to access it, but it was put in there by the developers, so I consider it native. I had the chance to try it at my friend's house and it was undescribable. I was totally and completely immersed in the game, and I was convinced I was actually there. I didn't actually get to the part where the alien starts appearing (about 1 hour in), but I imagine it's terrifying. The game itself without the Rift is more intense and stressful than it is scary, but I'm sure it'd go full pants-crapping mode in the Rift. It's also one of the only full-sized games to natively support the Rift at the moment. The Rift support isn't perfect, there's lots of clipping during scripted events, and that's why I imagine it's hidden in the files but it's still absolutely worth it if you have a Rift. Looking out the window into space in the beginning part of the game is jaw-dropping. Just try to not have a heart attack while playing.

I rate games from how much I enjoy them, and even though this game has a few problems, like the ending and final hours, it didn't affect the enjoyment of the game at all for me. Tenouttaten.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the Alien movies, specifically 1979 one, this game is an easy reccomendation.

It is structured like Bioshock, and also shares similar mechanics as it such as the way collectables reveal more of the story and are optional. Also, I've never played a game quite like it. I suppose you could say it is similar to Amnesia, but the AI is greatly smarter in this, it LEARNS FROM YOUR ACTIONS! And not only do you have to deal with the Alien, there are humans and synthetics to watch out for.

I genuinely feel this game has gives the movie justice and is a potential GOTY.

10/10

PS. No IGN, it is not 'too long' and the AI is not too 'unpredictable'. These are both good traits about a game and shouldn't be used against it in any way.

reviewText:
For fans of the original Alien this is a must. It feels a lot like the movie, the music is great, the setting is great. There's an excellent mood in general and it is scary. The most scary game I've played.

The alien is unseen for a long time. I've played for 5 hours and only been killed by it once, seen it three times maybe. But you die a lot if you are not careful, the alien isn't the only thing trying to kill you. The save points aren't as automatic as I sometimes thought, so you have to save a lot, using the save points scattered around the place.

Sometimes you have to try the same thing over and over again and that can become frustrating after a while and detract from the experience.

Graphicswise it's beautiful, some elements look old-fashioned, like some of the space junk that can be seen through windows because of the cartoonish way it loops, but that's the only negative commet so far.

Technically:
Performance is astonishing, I'm running 60FPS while both streaming via OBS and Shadowplay recording. My CPU is an ancient i7 860 moderately overclocked to around 3,4. GPU is a GTX 770 and I've got 16gb of ram. The game is on a mechanical drive and load times are very acceptable.

reviewText:
Alien Isolation is nothing short of a masterpiece, an uncompromised triple A production that stands so much nowdays for not being casual at all. It's infact so brutal and unforgiving at the highest difficulty setting, that you'll find yourself constantly struggling to stand the tension of being chased and stalked by the unstoppable , ruthless Xenomorph.
It's also a hearthfelt letter of love to Alien's fans and to the original movie's material: so true to the form that no other game got even close in history.

It also manages to do several things flawlessy.

- Visually beautiful, but still runs at maximum detail in your 90's bread toaster,
- Deeply and cleverly innovates the stealth genre in it's form and in the meantime sets a new landmark of excellence,
- It's tense, intimately frightening and terrifying like anything i've played before.

Great Games like this, usually get released once in a decade.
Buy it NOW ! And i mean.. NOW !

reviewText:
CORRIDORS OF THE YEAR
It's a game Alien universe always needed. Despite some notable shortcomings.

Pros:

+ Initial missions where you are getting acquainted with the station and Alien missions are the highlight of the game.
+ Alien is very unpredictable and cannot be killed, so you have to use tools you craft or find to distract it. Or better yet - try to sneak around without making any noise. The sense of dread is ever present. Its AI however is nothing innovative despite what reviews tell you, however it works.
+ No autosave, no save-anytime. There are emergency phone stations, that are admittedly well spread across Sevastopol - and that's the only way it happens. DO NOT ignore ANY possibility to save the game!
+ Retrofuturistic art is outstanding. Most of the decorations are direct copies from the Alien movie and the station crafted with them is very memorable. The well done lighting only adds to the atmosphere.
+ Sound is great. Motion tracker (which is the most important tool in the game and looking canonically badass at that) provides only vague clues to where enemies are, so you have to use your own ears too. Besides enemies hear noise too - which itself can be used as a tool. Even hitting the wall with a maintenance jack can work as a distraction.
+ Alien is not the only enemy, initial human/android sections are pretty creepy too. But only at first (see below).
+ Very adequately administered backtracking which I like since it always comes with some new stuff accessible here and there and adds to the sense that you indeed move around the station, instead of following a straight pass like other Alien-universe games.

Cons:

- Lategame missions that serve little purpose but to artificially extend the gametime. They are filled with androids and humans and some parts of them force you into a dull shooty combat. This alone delivers a huge hit to an otherwise interesting and fun game.
- Last missions are extremely scripted and linear, but despite that the game ends abruptly (still worth completing it however).
- Plot is rather weak and is full of cliches and predictable twists collected from across Alien movies.
- Being multiplatform for PS3/X360 forces the game to have small areas and makes loading screens another enemy.

Also to me it's better at being Bioshock (which it clearly tried to copy) in many ways than Bioshock itself.

reviewText: Alien: Isolation is pretty much the best Alien game out there, outclassing even the first two AvP games. The random unpredictable AI makes every encounter with alien memorable and the fact, that you are almost completely defenseless makes alien feel just as scary as in the first movie. The Sevastopol station is also a direct copy of Nostromo, so basicaly this game should be a no-brainer for every fan of the first movie. The game is incredibly lengthy (20 hours +/-), surprisingly replayable, very pretty and it has one of the best audio designs out there. So if you always wanted an Alien game that isn't about shooting hordes of tissue paper aliens, but instead about encounters with one unstoppable monster which is constantly hunting you, than your dream just came true.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
As a small preface, I have played the game for over 100 hours (some offline), and have played through it three and a half times, plus most of the DLC.

Alien: Isolation, unlike it's brand predecessor Aliens: Colonial Marines, stays true to the title by retaining the core horror elements that made Alien so great, and less focus on the sci-fi action that made Aliens so great.
As Amanda Ripley you come to Sevastopol for the Nostromo flight recorder to learn what happened to your mother, Ellen Ripley. All hell has broken lose on Sevastopol and now you face danger and terror at every turn, and at the center of it all, the Xenomorph.

Alien Isolation looks long and hard at Alien, and decides what built up suspense for that film was not the terrifying action moments, it was the slow-burning tension, and this game perfectly replicates that. The game paces itself phenomenally, electing to not even show the Alien until potentially an hour and half into the game, letting you get on edge, excited, anxious even.

Then when it comes, you wish you could go back to before in a heartbeat. The Alien is a cunning creature, learning your behavioral patterns and adapting to your strategies. Just because you could distract it with a noisemaker one time, doesn't gurantee that it will fall for the trick again. The terror is very real, and you truly feel as though you are being relentlessly hunted, with the chase only given up at chance times. You carefully think out your every move, you wait for it to leave and ponder if it will quickly run back, you watch in horror as it stalks your room, creeping towards the closet you reside in. Any noise you make can be heard, and likewise with everyone else. Just because you're being careful doesn't mean someone else in the area is, and the Alien will gladly come for them, sweeping you up as a bonus. The AI that Creative Assembly has constructed in this game is one of the most intelligent and adaptive programs to date.

As you wander Sevastopol, you sometimes get glances out of windows, giving you unparalleled splendor to be seen in the wide, expansive views of space, brought together with the hand down, phenomenal lighting effects. While graphics are very servicable, the game truly shines visually with it's dynamic lighting. Swinging lights on the ceiling bounce back and forth, illuminating different locations, while shadows are crisp and fluid. The models themselves have great facial construction, and the Alien is the best we've seen in years.

The game has so many little details added for atmosphere, it truly feels like you're on the set for Alien. Little Drinking Birds sit on desks, common utilites are exactly like in the films, and there is an obvious 1979 Future feel to the world. Computers take time to boot up, save stations require you to wait for the activation lights, and small maintenance minigames look and feel exactly like the film.

The game, while mostly linear, has a sort of Metroidvania feel to it despite you getting everything in order. Most of the time, items you recieve start out weak, but you find upgrades to them, allowing you to access new places and find new secrets. Going off the beaten path can reward you with crafting parts, blueprints, audiologs, and logs from the Nostromo itself.

The game allows you total stealth freedom, giving you numerous craftable devices, different paths to an objective, and dynamic hostiles, which interact with eachother in different ways. You can craft different devices like noisemakers, EMPs, Molotovs, and Pipe bombs, and employ them how you see fit. Missions feel dynamic, and while most have a certain reach a point, activate a thing, return, layout to them, the game keeps it fresh with scripted events, new paths unveiling, and different enemies.

The Alien however, remains the star of the show, but finds himself put to the side for some time to allow for greater world building and pacing. The game isn't afraid of missions dedicated to immersion, with one putting you on LV-426, the planet from Alien and Aliens. It's a complete love letter to the fans, with audio logs recorded by all the original actors (Minus Ian Holm, but you wouldn't think listening to the impersonator). The game spends a period of time without the Alien, most have complained, but what it really does is desenstise you to danger, so when the Alien returns, you get to relive all that introductary fear again. So much attention to world detail really pays off, and objects/locations/style of construction are all near identical to what you see in the film.

All this tension is complemented by the fantastic and dynamic score, rising in excitement when you are spotted, flaring at moments of action, and incurring deep feelings of dread.

Everything in the game just works so well with eachother, the game truly feels like an authentic experience. This is an unbelieveably high reccomendation for any Alien fans, and horror fans will find themselves completely enthralled with the experience. People not into horror games as well will most certainly find plenty to love about the horror hit of 2014.

As a final note, major credit is due to Creative Assembly, who until this point made turn based warfare games, for absolutely nailing everything about the horror genre, first person genre, and Alien universe on their first try.

reviewText:
I'm surprised I still hadn't written a review for Alien: Isolation.

First off, I'd like to say I'm a big big big fan of the Alien movie series. That said, my review might feel a bit bias, especially considering the Alien franchise never really had a game that could match up to it's awesomeness.

From the moment you step into Sevastapol, your life gains a whole new meaning, which is to make sure you've enough underwear to last through the game.

The controls are pretty simple, and the UI is minimal, which leaves you with a lot more space to enjoy the beautiful and incredibly well designed space and station. It's impossible for anyone that has seen Alien not to feel the nostalgia and the eventual goosebumps, as you walk around the station with Ripley, while death stares you from above, and the mesmerizing soundtrack does its best to activate your paranoid personality. From the constant noises around the vents, to the sound of its movement, the xenomorph poses a threat everyone, unless you hide under a bed, or inside a locker, just to have him, well, it, come close and sniff you well enough to feel your essence and grip you close, close enough for its, let's call it inner mouth, to kiss you, if you know what I mean.

That said, and considering you're still reading this, Alien: Isolation is probably the game you have been waiting for. You, a horror fan, a suspense fan, and above all, an Alien fan.

I can't really go further without spoiling all the fun"

reviewText:
Genre - First Person Survival Sci-Fi/Horror

After Gearbox ruining their chance at an Aliens game, I had low expectations of this despite the mostly positive reviews.

However, this is a very different game all together. You will feel like you are in an Alien film and it is not just you against the Alien. There are other threats just as deadly and other crew mates to negotiate with on your journey of survival. It reminds me of the Riddick game in style, which was very underated and feels like a true movie tie-in.

You will have to use your resources wisely and choose when to fight and when to run in order to survive. The graphics look nice and the interactions you have with other other characters and the environment feel real.

A great Alien game for fans of the films.
