reviewText:
9.5/10
Alien isolation is by far one of the best games i have ever played.Im not really a fan of its genre cause alot of games in horror kind off suck lately but this game was so good.

The game runs really well i never had any issues on my pretty average pc compared to other games that i have played that have serious frame rate drops at random points, this game had none of that.I really like they the graphics and textures, it made me feel i was in a place that was falling apart.One thing that wasn't great was the lip animation when people were talking like ricardo who was having a breakdown physically while talking calmly with his lips not matching what he was saying.

The gameplay was very fun and fair there was no weapon overpowered cause ammo is scarce. The alien gave me some serious scares that i didn't really expect which i really liked and the atmosphere was incredible that makes the game so tense and keeps you on edge no matter how relaxed or laid back you are.The alien though did sometimes act really annoying like he'd go up into a vent, come out of the vent and go back in the vent in the space of 15-20 seconds which was annoying thinking you could come out of your locker just to find he's still lurking.

The storyline was one of the best parts for me cause there's no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t happy ever after ending where characters were immune to death cause they were likable.The places you go and the development of the story was so good just finding out all the reasons for whats happening aboard the ship.The best thing about the story was that the story itself was good and long (at least 18 hours of gameplay just story) compared to other games i have played where i would be just ♥♥♥♥ing about just to keep the game going that bit longer.

I hardly ever write reviews but i felt the developers did such a good job it deserves every bit of praise it can get.
A MUST HAVE and By far one of the most enjoyable games i have ever played.

reviewText: It is easily the best horror game I had ever played.The atmosphere is intense and the graphics are truly next gen and god I love those lighting effects in this game, most of the time I get killed by the xeno while admiring the visuals but there are some problems with anti-aliasing.And whenever the xeno makes an appearance it's so damn intense, no other game makes you feel so tensed, most of the horror games are scripted and so it becomes easey when you play for the second time but here everything is unpredictable, the ai is one of the best I had seen, and the campaign will be tedious for some doing mundane tasks and getting no reward for anything you do might frustrate you, but I loved the game because the atmosphere, the developers nailed it and the xeno mixed with a very good soundtrack [mostly ambience kind of sound] completely overshadows the negatives of the game.And this is the exact game that alien fans were waiting for a long time.

reviewText:
You know that feeling when you turn off the lights at the bottom of the stairs, and you start running up because it feels like something is chasing you?
That's this game. Except worse, because there IS something chasing you, and it's a big, scary alien.

I waited until the game was at a good sale price before picking it up, however after completing it, I would say it would have been worth it at full price.

If you haven't seen the movie, or if it's been a while, I highly recommend watching it before playing. The audio and visual elements of the game are beautifully crafted, and pull directly from the film, with many subtle (and some not-so-subtle) tips of the hat to the original cinematic masterpiece.

The graphics are very pleasing, the engine is wonderfully optimized, and should run very well even without a top of the line PC.

My personal favorite part of this game is the audio. The musical score does a fantastic job of building tension, and seamlessly informs you when danger is lurking, not only without breaking immersion, but while adding to it. What could have been a boring 30 second wait for a tram, becomes an anxiety filled moment of Please please get here faster" as the creepy string music continues to rise

reviewText:
This game was a refreshing and welcome addition to my library of horror-survival games in that it steps out of the mainstream fit of an emphasis on combat when stealth fails. The staple of games such as the Resident Evil series, and the more recent Metro 2033 series, where combat is deemed a necessity. Here, combat is more of a last resort, and weaponry / ammo is quite rare.

Alien Isolation is an immersive, endless and well scripted dimension of raw fear. Having an indestructible predator on your heels in a rich, realistic environment reminiscent of an actual decommisioned space station where your senses of hearing and movement are actual game mechanics you can't overlook is excellently implemented. Paying attention to the environmentat acoustics is refreshingly frightening, and hgaving to observe your environment for clues on hiding spots and entry points for progress instead of a scripted map as staple games have done ensures you're permanently on edge. Amd that is good art that leaves a lasting impression.

Some minor gripes are the repetitive layout(s) and backtracking. However, they cannot make this game any less worth playing.

If you have a VR headset, please play this game with it, and good luck.

Individual section ratings:

1. Graphics:

Modern, well balanced, looks good, however, System requirements are friendly, and any mid-range gaming rig should handle this on Ultra without a problem. Minor glitches observed with aliasing. Very noticeable, adjust antialiaing manually from your GPU's control panel if necessary. TXAA not recommended, use FXAA as a last resort. Sweet spot is 4XMSAA.

2. Gameplay:

See notes above. Freaking excellent.

3. Acoustics / Sound:

Excellent. Whoever worked on the sound in this game took no shortcuts and pulled off a major feat. Its' simply perfect and well integrated into the game mechanics. The sound here pulls no punches.

Overall rating: 100/10. Go get this game, period.

PS: Vents aren't as safe as advertised. You'll get munched. A lot. Save frequently. And if something sounds off, believe it.
Also, prepare to die. A lot.
No one will hear you rage quit in space though.
The usage of a VR headset is at your own discretion.

reviewText:
I have not played any other Alien game, but Alien Isolation has become one of my favourite horror games!

The story was good, and you play as Ripley junior! The graphics were really great and the game is very optimised for pc!
I just love the sound and atmosphere of the game when you play, and I remember the chilling feeling of it when I think back of it. The gameplay never get boring since you have many tools to create from the items you find, to be able to breach forward from the douchy androids and protect yourself from the alien.
The androids and humans feels a bit scripted, but their ai is good. But when it comes to the alien... The aliens ai is not at all scripted and are terriffyingly great! It may be the smartest (and scariest) ai that I have ever encountered! In the first half of the game when I encountered the alien, it sometimes even made me turn off the game because of that I couldn't handle how scary it was when I was alone with it, with barely any items.
I played at medium difficulty, which was challenging. But the humans and androids felt like the most AAA games dumbed down ai which can't see or hear you far away (at medium difficulty). The alien also felt a tad too easy (still challenging) even thought that its supposed to have extremely good senses. But this is because the AI IS ORGINALLY PROGRAMMED GREAT AT NIGHTMAR DIFFICULTY, but is dumbed down to certain difficulties. So if you want the ai to be the most realistic and have full potential, you should play at the hardest difficulty.
If I'm going to complain about something else, it would be about the facial animation of the characters sometimes. Since the facial animations can look half done; a bit stiff and some parts like the eyebrows are not animated. Eitherway the animations in the game are great.

I am most likely going to replay the game in nightmare difficulty in the future, or at least a dlc :p
9/10

reviewText:
Do you like Alien of 1979 before Ridley Scott butchered the Alien universe with Prometheus? Then you should get this game and try it out. This is the definitive Alien game of all time and is easily the best in terms of storytelling, graphics, production values, sound, atmosphere etc. Now as all creations have their issues, so does this. However this is by far the best out there and the issues that are there will not ruin your game for you in terms of the overall experience. This game is in fact one of the most atmospheric and suspenceful games ever created! It is a gem in it's own little world. The other good thing about this game is that Creative Assembly understood to avoid the problems other movie franchise games often fail at. They deliberately designed the game to be similar in aspects to film but keep free of meddling with the lore or tangle themselves in to the movies plots which is often fatal as seen in the infamous Colonial Marines of 2013. This game follows Ripley's daughter and that besides the creature alien is all that ties the writers of this game down. Therefore they don't have to worry about butchering the story of the films or ruining peoples fond nostalgic memories of the iconic films. They are free to explore ideas and gameplay story wise without having to break the original concept.

This shows brains behind whoever went into thinking how this game should approach things. Eerily this game shares a lot with it's utterly failed predecessor Colonial Marines. Colonial Marines got patching after patching and after extensively playing that one, I was shocked to find eerily similar Nostromo map here + other similarities as if the makers of Isolation had actually went in and studied what was a failure in Marines and what worked (hardly anything with exception to maps) And pick and choose what to do properly in this game. There are a lot of things that I've found similar with this game with the obvious exception that Marines did them without soul and implemented poorly and this game took the idea and put serious effort and understanding into what they were making and why. ACM has a Stasis Interrupted DLC and in it are similarities with this (Blowing up the ship sequence) Obviously this one does not have the action based dynamics of ACM but it isn't purely Ridely Scotts Alien either. It feels like an amalgamation between the two with heavy leaning towards the mechanics of the original Alien film. Suspence rather than action, yet it's not Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell with aliens either. This game is faster in terms of pacing than Mr.Scott's original classic, and that's where you feel the amalgamation with other alien films. The faster pacing does not mean the game is short, by all means this game will give your money's worth. Maybe even too much depending on the gamers preference. As to my guessing of whether the similarities I find in ACM and this one (not gameplay wise) Are in fact real or not, I do however think no one in the gaming world could escape the abysmal sensation of ACM and it's aftermath. So in that sense I would consider a possibility of makers of Isolation to actually compare and try and figure out WHAT NOT TO DO here.

All in all it will be interesting to see whether CA can succesfully go forward with a good start and make this even better for DLC or even sequel. If they listen what people found frustrating with this yet understanding the good, they should at least be able to streamline the experience even more. Now if the next step would be similar to James Cameron's version but again with the understanding of not jumping in and trying to replicate the exact experience and end up spoiling it, but rather have the mood, atmosphere, ideas but not necessarily same people, locations etc. So that it stays fresh and free from breaking the past. That would be COOL in my books! Now we have the thriller version of Alien in videogame form, next step would logically be the suspence action ride of Aliens! Here's hoping!

reviewText:
After playing a lot of survival horror games, I thought I was desensitized at this point.  Alien Isolation not only proved me wrong, but it is one of the most terrifying games I've ever played.

There are two things that Alien Isolation gets right when it comes to survival horror.

The first is that the Alien is un-killable.  Many survival horror games rely on the player killing off their enemies (i.e. Dead Space, Resident Evil).  I've always felt that this diminishes the horror aspect, especially as the player often gets more proficient as the game wears on.  In Alien Isolation, while you can defend yourself against the Alien, you can never eliminate it.  It will always come back.

Scripted scares are also a staple of the survival horror genre.  However, scripted scares diminish once you know when to expect them.  And while this game does feature its share of scripted moments, the Alien in the game operates both at random and based on reactions to the environment.  The player is never exactly sure what will happen and often this resulted in unpredictable, yet incredibly cinematic moments.

In one instance, I was being pursued by a hostile guard who had shot at me.  I escaped down a corridor into a dead end.  I peaked out from the room to see the guard slowly making his way towards me.  At that exact moment, the door behind the guard opened up to reveal the hulking silhouette of the Alien, having been attracted by the gunshots.  I ducked my head back into the room to hide while listening to the dying screams of the guard.  It was one of the most singularly cinematic moments in the game and yet completely unscripted.

Graphically, this game is gorgeous.  Having re-watched the original Alien recently, I was amazed at painstaking effort the designers took to recreate the designs from the film.  Everything from the grills on the lights, the design of the vents, to the prevalence of CRT screens and giant buttons, this game is a beautiful homage to the film.

If the graphics are amazing, the sound design is on another level.  This game relies heavily on terrifying the player by what they can often hear, but not always see.  From the Alien's thudding footsteps to the steady beeps of the motion tracker, the sound design is just fantastic.

If the game does have its weaknesses, it is in the narrative, pacing and some of the mechanics.  Puzzle-wise, the game isn't much more than a door-opening simulator.  There are some hacking" mini-games involving matching up symbols or timing button presses.  But overall
date: it's basic stuff.  The narrative isn't particularly compelling either.  There's an Alien on board
hoursPlayed: and in the most cliche twist in the Alien universe
voteText: the Weyland-Utani corporation is involved.  It's not the most compelling story
helpfulPercent: but it serves as the basic framework for the player's action.\n\nAlien Isolation is a stellar game.  While it does have weaknesses
votesHelpful: it's aesthetics and ability to invoke sheer terror more than make up for it.  If you like survival horror
votesTotal: don't pass up this game."

reviewText:
So i just finished playing Alien Isolation's main story mode after 15 hours on medium difficulty. In this review i will cover some basics about the game, things i enjoyed, things that i didn't like so much, my final statement and a score out of 100.

So to start with, there are many aspects of this game that make it great, and these in my opinion outweigh the bad points completely. We've seen many game titles under the Alien and Predator franchises such as the action based AVP and the James Cameron take on Colonial Marines, where we had big guns, trained marine allies and a bad attitude. Alien Isolation however, attempts to re-install the original terror and fear we had of the Ridley Scott's monster. It does this by stripping you, the player, down to the extreme basics. You don't have any prior survival or combat training, you're simply just a human stuck on a very large broken spaceship with no way off.

The game is a survival horror, meaning you basically have to make the best of a very bad situation and do whatever it takes to survive. So let's talk about your options:

As Amanda Ripley, daughter of Ellen Ripley, you are trained in mechanics to some extent, and you can use this to your advantage by picking up world items and combining them to create devices or medical supplies. You can create smoke bombs to escape sticky situations, noisemakers to distract enemies while you slip by unnoticed and EMP mines to deal with the on board crazy synthetic androids and many more. You will find guns as you progress through the story line, but you will quickly realize that they are only a final resort. Ammo is very scarce for anything other than the Flamethrower and they are almost entirely useless against the Alien and the tough Androids. They are however, suitable methods of dealing with the crazed population of humans quickly.

The Alien: The Alien is the star of this game, it's the big bad boss which you cannot fight, all you can do is hide from it and prey that it doesn't find you. You can use crafted devices to lure it out of your way, but if you choose to do this too often, the alien will wise up and stop playing ball. For example, you could throw a flare across the room, and the Alien would follow it and become mesmerized by it for a short while. The next flare you throw, the Alien may see it and already know what it is, so there is no need for it to examine it or walk over to it. The next time, you may find that the alien instead of looking at the flare, it turns and tries to find the source of where it came from, so if you don't move, then you're basically screwed.

Stealth and Sneaking: The game is largely based of sneaking around and hiding. In the world there are many places the player can choose to hide, such as lockers, under beds and under desks. These are all a temporary solution, because if the Alien catches a glimpse of you, or hears a noise in your area, it is going to stay around allot longer, giving you less time and opportunity to move away.

Pros:

The Fear: My favorite thing about this game, was the constant feel of dread. The Alien is progressively hunting Amanda throughout the game after a certain point, meaning you're never truly sure if you're safe or not. There are points in which the alien is scripted to appear, but it doesn't entirely keep to just scripted events. On your motion tracker, you occasionally see movement quickly dart over your head through the vents system. This is not a world ambiance mechanic at all, because if you make enough noise, no matter where you are, the Alien will appear to punish you. Death in this game from the Alien is 80% of the time instant. Once it's seen you, if you don't have a flame thrower, or some kind of explosive, then you are going to die straight away. Once it's got hold of you, you're dead.

The Clever AI: The Aliens AI is by far the most advanced artificial intelligence I've ever seen. It responds to sound, sight and maybe even possibly smell. However, it mainly works off sound. The Alien doesn't let up either, because if it hears you in a certain area, it will refuse to move away until it's caught you, leaving you with few choices such as: Duck, cover, crawl, progress or distracting it.

The Length: For a 60$ game, you would expect a double figure in the amount of playtime. For me it took 15 hours, for others I've heard it take upward of 20 hours. It all depends on how you play and the difficulty. I played through on medium because i suck at stealth games, but i did surprisingly well and made progress very fast as i refused to stick around in areas where the alien was.

Survival mode: This mode is great for scaring your friends. It throws you into a small area with a couple of missions to beat and a roaming Alien. There's also a timer, putting pressure on you to get the best time. You're given some basic supplies and craftables, and a Flamethrower with a few good shots. It's a great competitive mode to play with friends, and it is the first mode you should show to anyone new.

Cons:

The Story itself: While the length of the game in my opinion was perfect, it could have benefited from a better story line. Although another survival horror title Dead Space 1" borrowed heavily off the concepts in the original film

reviewText:
Score: 9 / 10
Price/Value: $40-
Time: 18 hours (Incl. minor ID tag/log hunting)

**Does not include Crew Expendable / DLC yet** (Havn't played it)

Well folks, we've been waiting for an excellent Alien game and here it is! Fans of things like Amnesia, Outlast, Penumbra, etc will find a common game mechanic in hiding as your main form of defense. You -do- get some weapons and tools but I will get into those a little later.

You play Amanda Ripley, daughter of Ellen Ripley from the original film. You are looking for the blackbox from the Nostromo which you heard was recently recovered in search of your mother. This opens up some nice Nostromo logs which help reference the original film more.

You spend most of the game either hiding from the alien or combating androids.

Weapons such as a stun baton, maintenance jack, revolver, shotgun and boltgun are all effective against androids. The alien is best combated via stealth and planned movement. A handful of distractions and saves exist versus the alien...noisemakers, flares, smoke bombs, etc...which I found I never used. Molotovs and the flamethrower cause the alien to retreat into the nearest vent giving you roughly 3 - 5 seconds of freedom to move before the alien returns.

Gameplay-wise there is nothing special here. It's the world that Alien takes place in that makes the game amazing. From the growls of the alien on the prowl to the glow of android eyes models are fantastic to look at. Key animations and movements from the original film make an appearance that Alien fans will enjoy. The motion tracker is solid and easy to read. The station, derelict, space and vent ducts are all highly authentic to the universe and feel like you are stepping into it yourself.

I was highly reserved coming into this so I was pleasently surprised with how entertained I was. Aside from ID tag / log hunting this game really is a one shot wonder like most story games. I definitely recommend picking it up for $40 or less. The value is there and this might end up being my Game of the Year.

reviewText:
To put it short: this is how a game based on a movie franchise should be like.

Creative Assembly managed to capture the style and the terrifying atmosphere of the first Alien movie from 1979 almost perfectly with flawlessly designed and highly detailed art, and a simply impeccable sound design. This way, in addition to the fantastic AI of the xenomorph, the game managed to keep me on my toes for most of its playing time.

That's not to say the game would be completely without flaws, though: occasionally, the plot drags its feet, and having to replay certain sections multiple times due to the saving system can be annoying.

The Mac port by Feral is also close to perfection: the game ran stable and mostly absolutely smooth on my 2012 rMBP.

reviewText:
Edit: Valve, you really need to fix this review submission system. I can only submit short reviews right now and need to edit to get them longer.

Contrary to the game's description, this is not really a survival game. Sure, the goal is not to die, but that is true of a very large number of games. What this game actually is is a highly scripted stealth action fps horror game which often plays like a groundhog day nightmare (die a horrible death, but learn where enemies are so you can hopefully get a little farther before dying again).

With that out of the way, I want to say that I wanted to like this game. Being able to explore a space station is a lot of fun, and the metroidvania item progression to unlock new parts of the station had a lot of potential. Unfortunately, this game does have some major issues that ultimately shifted my perception away from fun to annoyance by the time I was done with the game.

First off, the good points. The atmosphere is perfect for an Aliens game, and the (somewhat) freeform Metroidvania exploration was a nice touch where getting new items would unlock new areas to explore. You have guns, but are heavily incentivized to use stealth due to the severely limited ammo and not wanting to attract attention.

Now (unfortunately) to the bad points. Note that I was playing on Novice in hopes of minimizing these so take into account that they will be exacerbated on higher difficulties.

The checkpoint saving system is a PITA. When there are many things that can very quickly kill you, and the heavy stealth focus making for often slow progress, it can easily be 15-20 minutes between checkpoints (even taking into account backtracking to find one). Deaths mean a significant time loss and significantly contributed to my annoyance. The amount of time you stand starting blankly at the save points watching the lights is also completely unnecessary.

Guns are in desperate need of a rebalance. The first gun you get (the revolver) is so pathetically weak (even on novice) and takes so long to reload as to be essentially useless. Either it needed to be significantly more powerful or should have been replaced with a semi-auto pistol with larger clips and faster reloads. The flamethrower goes through fuel too quickly (unless you think a quick half-second burst should use a full liter of fuel) but at least ammo is relatively plentiful in spite of that annoyance. The shotgun has way too loose of a spead (this unfortunately is a sin propogated by far too many shooters) and the bolt gun has too large of a reticle so it's only useful at shotgun ranges anyways. Pipe bombs aren't considered weapons by the weapon scanners (there's a mission where you have to leave your guns behind) but are by far the most powerful means of killing things in the game. Plus, the materials to build them are much more common than ammo.

The battery eating flashlight trope seriously needs to die. Even in the relatively power hungry flashlights of years past they lasted significantly longer than they do in this (and far to many other) games. Flashlight use is discouraged enough as is with the extra attention it draws. At least there's only a handful of places in the game that are actually dark enough to need the flashlight.

Quicktime events and minigames add nothing to games like this and only serve to add another layer of annoyance, forcing you to master a pesky little timed button pushing game that adds no real content. A lot of AAA games from this era did this unfortunately, hopefully they got enough negative feedback to convince the devs not to include it so much in future titles. The computer terminals and rewires don't pause the game and lock you in while using them with no quick way out, so it's very easy to die even if you hear an enemy coming up behind you. When you do abort, you completely log out so it takes a significant amount of time to get back in if you managed to survive being interrupted.

The AI can be very inconsistent. Sometimes they're completely oblivious to your presence, other times they see you from what seems like a mile away. All the enemies exhibit this behavior. The alien has the ability to teleport to your location and randomly appear out of nowhere, killing you so often that it ceases to be scary and simply becomes aggravating.

The scripted events are also quite annoying. There are quite a few scripted events that drag you out of control (or simply are abused to provide a cheap jump scare that you'll be numb to by the end) and put you on a sometimes lengthy detour that doesn't really add anything. The entire ending sequence (between extending the maintence platform and releasing the clamps is a prime example of this, and felt entirely unnecessary.

Normally I applaud a game for having lots of content provided I'm having fun, but this game overall felt like it had overstayed its welcome by the end and did not need to be as long as it was. The Metroidvania elements were ultimately wasted by the end since there wasn't really an indication of when it would be a good time to go back and visit the rooms I couldn't get into before, and now that I've been annoyed I'm not about to go back and replay to go find everything.

Overall, not a bad game per se, but definitely needed another rebalance and editing pass. It's a decent stealth horror game so pick it up on sale if you like those types of games or are an Aliens fan, otherwise stay away. Not really worth the full asking price IMHO.

reviewText:
This game has a feel for the new when it comes to the Alien franchise. For me, Alien: Isolation was a 15 hour struggle of cat and mouse, the alien hunting me down and sniffing me out; the impact of the first few encounters with the monster felt huge.

The game's been a critical success, getting a lot of great press and making many game of the year lists. Steam at the moment of writing has 5000+ reviews logged which are flagged as 'very positive'. I too would agree, this a great game – outstanding really – but certainly not without its problems which I found close to immersion breaking.

I enjoyed the way the game forces you to sneak. It suits the narrative of the game and makes your controlled protagonist's actions seem believable. I believe Amanda Ripley would sneak around this space station, the survivors and androids being relatively unpredictable along with the alien being lethal. You sneak to avoid the risk of alarm and I thought this was very fitting.

On the other hand, I found constantly sneaking around very tiresome. The alien controls the pacing of the game far too much and as a player you're forced to go along with how the AI has been developed. Stay still and the games pacing is wrecked - move too fast and you get punished. I found it frustrating that the AI seemingly does not adapt to the individual player but rather, you find yourself adapting to the AI's systems.

The uncertainty of the games rules is interesting; throw a flare and distract the alien for a while knowing that it's now close in your vicinity and can potentially hunt you down. Yet after a while the game does show fault here. With enough subtlety and patience you can sneak past any threat.

The narrative is paperthin, and I think it's the games rules which cause a very undercooked story. I focused on saving my game far too much than what was going on in the world. Ripley's own story became tedious for me, as my biggest objective was saving the game. Really, the game became a save-area-loot style game, with the story not mattering much.

Tension is a huge part of Alien: Isolation, and the game creates an amazingly tense atmosphere through the aliens empowerment and your lack of power over the creature.

However, this focus on challenge to create tension was another problem for me. It made the game feel extremely linear and I didn't explore the world much because of the constant threat. My influence in the game world didn't matter so long as I could save the game. The actual narrative itself is not so great either. Frankly, I did not care much for Amanda Ripley or her crew – which is surprising because the world of Alien: Isolation is teeming with nuggets of info and audio dialogs.

If the narrative does not drive this game – and it really doesn't – then it's about putting the player into situations against the alien and having that play out. Indeed, that is enthralling and quite incredible at times. But the games length also turns this into tedium.

It must be said, none of the above is game breaking either. This the first 'survival-horror' game I've played and truly enjoyed in many years (since maybe the first Resident Evil). The atmosphere of the game is wonderful and visually its jaw-droppingly faithful to the 1979 classic. Incidentally, I'm not a huge fan of the film, yet the visual similarities to Ridley Scott's universe in Alien: Isolation are breathtaking.

Despite the problems above, this is a fine game for reasons already explained in the dozens of reviews found elsewhere.

reviewText:
How to begin with Alien Isolation? To start with this is a survival horror game to say in the most definitive terms. Essentially the whole station is full of angry redneck personel on the deck alongside a hungry hungry alien who picks everyone off. As much as I wanted to enjoy this the interface was clunky. Aquiring blueprints to craft items is an ok idea but I would of prefer a lot more usable items since you are quite literly running and hiding for your life.

Atmosphere really is captured, 10/10 and the use of old cassettes, rewiring ect is great. Even the intro of the 20th century was a nice touch though I really really really can not stand not being able to escape those publisher advertisng at the start of the game. I really hated the game for this and any game for that matter.

One of my biggest drawbacks was also item usage, the amount of guiding to open latch A, turn to unlock B drove me insane. I also have disputes over the actual personal considering the amount of firepower on the station agaist a single alien, it surpises me that that massive space station is in such chaos when they could of easily taken down 1 alien.

Suprisingly after Rome Total War 2 being an utter disaster and the large feedback of Aliens colonel Marines being one of the biggest public shams with its falsified demo I had little hope for this game. I am going to recommend this one just for those who enjoyed the game FEAR. I would not recommend those who enjoyed thief 1-3 , Dishonored, Deadspace simply due to the nature of combat and violece in comparison.

I also would not recommend this game to those who wanted something like the film Aliens (2nd film) who want to shoot a lot of stuff up with trained marines, hopefully they can build something from this but I dont give my hopes up.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game.  It did what a good horror game should do and scared me.  It did what a good film license should do and was faithfull to the license, while extending the licensed universe in a way that was consitant with it and good for gameplay.

On one occasion the game uses a flashback to let you take part in events in the Alien universe that they could not shoe horn into the main plot, which is inconsistant with the rest of the game, but had this Alien fanboy squeeling with delight.

The levels, interfaces, ambience were spot on recreations of the set and props from the Alien movie.  I could not be more pleased in this regard.  The graphical and acustic fidelity are amazing, attention to detail right down to animating the coulds of the gas giant that is hanging outside the window.  Isolation has some scary and beautifull set peices.

I am one of those players that likes the whole use both mouse button then press down" to pull a big lever that requires boith hands.  This kind of mechanic is used effectively several times throughout the game

reviewText:
Ok, so this is my official review on one of the Greatest Alien saga games to date!
First, do NOT expect a run & gun shooter on this one, you are setting yourself up for premeditated failure. So, what to expect in this game is some HARDCORE stealth and fast thinking! If you don't like a challenge and/or hate the Alien series, MOVE ON NOOB!!!
However, I will recommend this game to almost anyone. If you like the Alien series, you are in for a REAL treat! I will not spoil what you will find in the game, but I will say that the Alien is increadibly smart!!!! It will learn your movements, it does not run on a set path, and it WILL FIND YOU!!!! Your adrenaline will be running so hard that when you go to enter the code into a door, you will quite often enter it wrong because of pure fear. That's just how very well this game is made! The graphics & effects are BEAUTIFUL!!! Even on lower graphics cards, you will not be disappointed. It's very well refined and even follows the Alien move deleted scenes that I had long forgotten. So worth the time and SO worth the money. NO REGRETS HERE!!!!! Curious? Try it and see for yourself! Also, if you scare easy, keep some toilet paper handy. ;)

reviewText:
A terrifying,lovingly crafted cat and mouse experience that keeps you on edge for most of its duration.

Pros:

-absolutely wonderful in its recreation of the Alien universe,the station,spaceships and equipment designs are spot on.
-amazing sound design,everything sounds as it should and the sounds itself are essential in helping you know where danger lies
-very good soundtrack that dinamically changes depending on what's happening
-good graphics
-interesting story that ties nicely with the movie
-very good alien AI

Neutral:

-no save everywhere,you're tied to save stations
-starts out fairly slow

Cons:

-a few cheap deaths,sometimes it comes down to blind luck
-a few textures are not as nice as the rest
-human opponents are more often just annoying rather than a challenge
-can drag a bit sometimes

Overall Alien Isolation is an amazing game when you consider it for what it is,that is a frightening experience that throws you against an alien and an hostile space station with little means to actually fight back.
The tension while you are chased by the alien or other hostiles,the frantic scrambling to try and find an hiding place while trying to understand where your enemy lies,trying to manage your ammo/item counts...all into an universe recreated to firmly follow what we saw in the '79 movie.
Sure it's not a game for everyone,its not action oriented,its pacing can get lost at times,sometimes it might be frustrating...but it's basically the best Alien game to date and one of the few I genuinely found unnerving,I fully recommend it.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fantastic game.

The first thing that deserves mention is the homage it pays to its source material. Everything in Alien: Isolation looks like it was ripped directly out of the movie. All of the aesthetics-- the visuals, the sound, the music, all spot on. The computers especially. CA totally nailed it.

The game itself is great, but not perfect. Like most stealth games, the AI is lacking at times, but that is to be expected. Mechanically, it is all very sound. The controls, weapons, actions, animations, etc are all very consistent and work well. The crafting system seems a bit unnecessary, but doesn't take away from the game. I expereinced very few bugs the entire game. Maybe two minor graphical errors.

The campaign is pretty lengthy (~15 hours for me), and the survival mode offers quite a bit more replay value. I picked up the season pass too, but haven't played any of that content yet. It assuredly adds even more to do.

Anyway, if you're into Alien at all, or sci-fi stealth/survival games, you should definitely give this a go.

reviewText: Of the horror games I've played, this is easily my favorite, there's an atmosphere of constant tension, the graphics are beautiful and very faithful to the original movie, the story and acting are generally spot-on, and the levels are well-designed for the most part. That said, the levels can be rather large and it's definitely possible to get lost if you aren't paying attention, and the save points can be spaced a good distance apart in some areas, meaning you could get bumped back 20 minutes if you get killed. Overall, I'd rate this at least a 9.7 out of 10, and recommend it to fans of the Alien franchise and survival horror fans in general.

reviewText:
I don't understand how a studio deeply rooted in turn (and real time) strategy can pull off an amazing take on the survival horror genre (with the alien franchise no less).

Gameplay is great, minimal handholding past the first few stages in terms of gameplay (such as sneaking or scavenging) but the game will guide you to your rough destination or objective (unless you are playing nightmare mode, where there is no hud, a broken motion tracker and no map)
Story ties in well with Alien, having logs from the Nostromo (including the flight recorder) and even a pair of short sequences made reenacting parts of the movie (as DLC).

Not playing this is almost a crime to yourself.

reviewText: So many Alien games have failed to live up to expectations over the years that it's refreshing to experience the wonder and terror that Sevastopol has to offer in Alien: Isolation(A:I).  You take the role of Amanda Ripley, Ellen Ripley's daughter, in her quest to find out what happened to her mother.  The first thing you'll experience with this game is its atmosphere.  It perfectly recreates the look and feel of the first Alien film with its retro-futuristic claustrophobic environments.  It's such an aesthetically beautiful game that you'll often find yourself marvelling at the various elements within the environments while a 'Working Joe' or the Alien runs you down (well not the Working Joes, they just walk you down).\n\nThe gameplay itself is highly innovative taking mechanics we're used to, like firing a pistol, and tweaking them that adds to the true horror experience.  Using tools and weapons in A:I takes up valuable time and/or resources forcing you to strategize effective choices that will see you to the end of the game.  For example when aiming the revolver you have to wait a small amount of time for the reticule decrease in size maximizing your accuracy, but while this is happening your target/s are advancing and they certainly take more than one well aimed bullet to put down.  Do you have enough time to aim
hoursPlayed: aim before they get you?"\n\nEven the simple 'Save' mechanic has been overhauled to give an experience that at times is utter horrifying.  There’s nothing quite like hearing those heavy Alien footsteps getting louder and louder as the 'Save Station' slowly beeps through its progress.  Often you'll also approach a 'Save Station' to see
voteText: "SAVE PROGRESS - HOSTILES NEARBY".  "Hmmmmmm." you'll think to yourself.\n\nThe main enemies are the 'Working Joes' and the 'Alien' both of which have their own unique behaviours that you will have to figure out in order to overcome.  But I will not spoil you guys with that information as understanding how to deal with these two enemies is part of the adventure and the longer it takes you to figure them out the longer you'll be afraid for.  But what I will say is that both enemies are fantastic elements within the game.  The 'Working Joes' are by far the creepiest humanoids I have ever had the pleasure of dealing with in a game.  With their Michael Myer faces and their robotic voices they still fill me with dread even after 70 hours of game time.  The Alien on the other hand is an unpredictable force of nature that will force you to whimper under the hospital bed every time it pops out.  But even that is sometimes not enough
helpfulPercent: in A:I no hiding spot is permanent
votesHelpful: if you stay under that bed or in the locker long enough the Alien will rather unceremoniously rip you right out of there adding to the constant fear of being utterly helpless at times.\n\nReinforcing the experience of Sevastopol is its sounds.  From the slight humming of the ambience to the distant shriek of a ventilated Alien
votesTotal: A:I completely hits all the nails on the head.  With the audio nothing is left to doubt
votesFunny: you know what’s around you just by keeping your ears open and constantly your reminded that you’re in a hostile environment.  If you can't hear the alien moving around the vents above you
commentsCount: then it’s the sound of something on Sevastopol failing that you'll most likely have to deal with later.\n\nThen

reviewText:
This game is awesome. It is frustrating, unforgiving and dull at the same time.

It succeeds at establishing and maintaining a tense sci-fi horror atmosphere, which is no small feat. I believe this is what the game tries to accomplish first and foremost, and it succeeds admirably. A solid 8/10.

The Good The narrative. The story is on par with the first two alien movies. Very recognizable. Similar pace, similar narrative devices, similar twists. To some, it may be too similar to be exciting in any way, because hardly anything happens that you did not see coming. Still. Some things you expect to happen may be a while in coming, and others happen surprisingly early.
Some environments are modeled very closely after the movie sets. Great atmosphere there. Great sense of purpose to these sections.
The Alien has a proper AI, as opposed to being entirely pre-scripted in its behaviour. Keeps players on their toes.
Amanda is an engineer, and she can put together helpful makeshift devices from scrap and raw material to help you survive.
The alien animations are pretty well done. Especially when it gets you. And it will.
The sound design is fantastic. Big plus in a stealth title.
The Bad Many environments are too generic a sci-fi tunnel, corridor, hall, or room with too many fake, forced accessories like boxes and barrels around. Doom 3 and Dead Space-like interior design. These sections feel generic, there's no believable in-game purpose to them. To the extent that they support the function of a location (med/tech junction/energy etc.), they are often merely servicable. There are exceptions, but all in all, once you finish the game, you'll remember only a select few locations for what they were.
The alien AI is frustrating, and not very convincing. You may like it for its unpredicatbility. To me it feels quite predictable in the sense that you can't to jack-all once the alien is out and looking for you. You need to wait for it to disappear in the vents for it to be somewhat safe to do anything. On easier diffictulties you might get away with some stunts, but not in general. Not if you don't know your surroundings yet.

The AI leash is maybe a little too tightly centered around the player, and it definitely is tugging the alien too often in the player's direction. The alien leaving a room, then promptly turning around, searching again. Then again. Then maybe running off in a different direction for 5 secs before the AI tugs it back. The alien sections are tense for that reason, yes, but when you're playing a section for the first time, not knowing your way around you're going to die a lot or wait a lot or both.

The alien has a proper AI that leads to emergent situations as opposed to the occasional prescribed scripted event. It makes it more likely for the game to just decide that you must die now. X-Com style. Like when there's a very small tight-quarters section that you have to cross, and the game decides to basically drop the alien out of a vent and almost into your lap. Here's your reload button. Luck is definitely a bigger factor than in other stealth based games, especially when you try to conserve your resources. Sucks if the last save is 5 minutes of tedious sneaking around hostile androids away.

The use of craftable items is mostly not incentivised. Using your little helper devices should be more core to a stealth game. As it is, these things are mostly obscure. Maybe it's just me, but the game is unforgiving when you slip up. Here's your 5-10 minute section with unskippable dialog that you must replay if you slip up. Why on earth would you prefer to stage distractions" which are basically "attractions" for anything around
date: if there seems to be a valid way to just sneak by. What good is a "smoke bomb" or "pipe bomb" except to shout "over here
recommended: here I am"? Does not feel like the AI should be dumb enough to fall for it in the way it does. So it hardly ever feels like using your gadgets would be really helpful. Even though it is pretty effective if you try. It's just not really plausible behaviour that it triggers. Maybe the overall sense of dread and horror the game establishes so successfully is at odds with the dumb effects your gadgets trigger when used.\n\nMaybe if there was a way to quicksave
hoursPlayed: the player would be more inclined to experiment with the effects of gadgets
voteText: but if the game is penalizing eperimentation
helpfulPercent: you'd probably rather wait for an opportunity and sneak by
votesHelpful: unless you saw no other way.\n\nThrow a noisemaker somewhere. A crew of looters is going to run over there to look at the thing. The alien too. They might just ignore each other while the funny noise takes their interest. Then
votesTotal: once they want to 'disperse' again
votesFunny: they may jump on each other's throats. Or not. I've had an alien just run straight back into the vents from a situation like this.\n\nThe snaking mechanics with regards to human opponents is awful. If you're used to Thief
commentsCount: Spliter Cell
column16: or Styx-like mechanics you're going to have to adjust. Human opponents are somewhat odd in their perception. Light and shadow
column17: distance

column20: but that line is somewhat hard to trace. You'll need to get used to it the way you needed to get used to die at Dark Souls before you embraced the mechanics :)\nAll in all a solid experience
column21: and the weak or frustrating bits are just a minor annoyance in comparison with the experience as a whole.\n\nHope to see Amanda in a Sequel again. Preferably in more memorable environments
column22: and with more plausible AI behaviour."

reviewText:
Stealthy horror survival games aren't normally high on my list of prefered genres, so I bought the game solely to try the unofficial experimental VR support.

After having spent 17+ hours completing the campaign, I must say that it has been the most intense, stressful gaming experience I've ever endured.

Intense because the Alien universe from the original 1979 movie is so incredibly faithfully recreated, that experiencing it in VR immersed me like no other game ever has before. BRAVO to the developers, it's a work of art.

Stressful for two reasons:

The primary reason being that an unkillable predator is hunting you down most of the game, even when you're performing tasks that'd normally pause" in-game time
date: like e.g. using a computer or inserting your keycard in a "save game" terminal. In VR you're literally looking over your shoulder hoping noone or nothing will ambush you.\nSadly I found the Alien's behaviour to be so absolutely unpredictable at times
recommended: that it simply ruined some stages of the game for me. The first few times it killed me during a specific part of the map
hoursPlayed: it got the adrenaline going
voteText: and I felt psycked to retry it. But after having replayed the same savegame 20 times
helpfulPercent: still feeling that it was an absolute coin toss when that oversized slimy rat would drop from a vent shaft right behind me
votesHelpful: my enthusiasm also died.\n\nDespite this
votesTotal: I did mostly have an absolute thrill ride scavenging
votesFunny: crafting
commentsCount:
hiding and sometimes killing my way through the game. Firing that bolt gun into the face of one of those "super" synthetics has to be one of the most satisfying things ever.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely amazing.

It's the best Survival Horror game ever made. EVER. None other came even close to the SHEER TERROR this put me through. I played this in the dark with headphones at full volume.

I sweat, crouched into my chair, screamed (hundreds of times), jumped up and hurt myself. It's that good.

As far as an FPS goes, this has the best single player campaign I've ever played. The immersion is so intense, I almost put it aside before even meeting the Alien because I was so afraid.

I highly recommend watching the movies before playing, in order to fully appreciate the artistic dedication that was put into producing this. In my opinion it's far better than all the movies.

Alien Isolation is the kind of work the Alien franchise deserved all along.

I enjoyed this game.  It did what a good horror game should do and scared me.  It did what a good film license should do and was faithfull to the license, while extending the licensed universe in a way that was consitant with it and good for gameplay.

On one occasion the game uses a flashback to let you take part in events in the Alien universe that they could not shoe horn into the main plot, which is inconsistant with the rest of the game, but had this Alien fanboy squeeling with delight.

The levels, interfaces, ambience were spot on recreations of the set and props from the Alien movie.  I could not be more pleased in this regard.  The graphical and acustic fidelity are amazing, attention to detail right down to animating the coulds of the gas giant that is hanging outside the window.  Isolation has some scary and beautifull set peices.

reviewText:
Ok, so this is my official review on one of the Greatest Alien saga games to date!
First, do NOT expect a run & gun shooter on this one, you are setting yourself up for premeditated failure. So, what to expect in this game is some HARDCORE stealth and fast thinking! If you don't like a challenge and/or hate the Alien series, MOVE ON NOOB!!!
However, I will recommend this game to almost anyone. If you like the Alien series, you are in for a REAL treat! I will not spoil what you will find in the game, but I will say that the Alien is increadibly smart!!!! It will learn your movements, it does not run on a set path, and it WILL FIND YOU!!!! Your adrenaline will be running so hard that when you go to enter the code into a door, you will quite often enter it wrong because of pure fear. That's just how very well this game is made! The graphics & effects are BEAUTIFUL!!! Even on lower graphics cards, you will not be disappointed. It's very well refined and even follows the Alien move deleted scenes that I had long forgotten. So worth the time and SO worth the money. NO REGRETS HERE!!!!! Curious? Try it and see for yourself! Also, if you scare easy, keep some toilet paper handy. ;)

reviewText: Hide and seek simulator 2014.   10/10
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A terrifying,lovingly crafted cat and mouse experience that keeps you on edge for most of its duration.

Pros:

-absolutely wonderful in its recreation of the Alien universe,the station,spaceships and equipment designs are spot on.
-amazing sound design,everything sounds as it should and the sounds itself are essential in helping you know where danger lies
-very good soundtrack that dinamically changes depending on what's happening
-good graphics
-interesting story that ties nicely with the movie
-very good alien AI

Neutral:

-no save everywhere,you're tied to save stations
-starts out fairly slow

Cons:

-a few cheap deaths,sometimes it comes down to blind luck
-a few textures are not as nice as the rest
-human opponents are more often just annoying rather than a challenge
-can drag a bit sometimes

Overall Alien Isolation is an amazing game when you consider it for what it is,that is a frightening experience that throws you against an alien and an hostile space station with little means to actually fight back.
The tension while you are chased by the alien or other hostiles,the frantic scrambling to try and find an hiding place while trying to understand where your enemy lies,trying to manage your ammo/item counts...all into an universe recreated to firmly follow what we saw in the '79 movie.
Sure it's not a game for everyone,its not action oriented,its pacing can get lost at times,sometimes it might be frustrating...but it's basically the best Alien game to date and one of the few I genuinely found unnerving,I fully recommend it.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fantastic game.

The first thing that deserves mention is the homage it pays to its source material. Everything in Alien: Isolation looks like it was ripped directly out of the movie. All of the aesthetics-- the visuals, the sound, the music, all spot on. The computers especially. CA totally nailed it.

The game itself is great, but not perfect. Like most stealth games, the AI is lacking at times, but that is to be expected. Mechanically, it is all very sound. The controls, weapons, actions, animations, etc are all very consistent and work well. The crafting system seems a bit unnecessary, but doesn't take away from the game. I expereinced very few bugs the entire game. Maybe two minor graphical errors.

The campaign is pretty lengthy (~15 hours for me), and the survival mode offers quite a bit more replay value. I picked up the season pass too, but haven't played any of that content yet. It assuredly adds even more to do.

Anyway, if you're into Alien at all, or sci-fi stealth/survival games, you should definitely give this a go.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The game has a few flaws here or there... But they are not really relevant enough to go over.

I have around 45-50 hours of actual play time. (55 hours on Steam, but some of that was pause, and just title screen AFK)
Overall it is a great game, highly recommended to any First Person Perspective gamer fans, any Alien gamer fans, and/or any Horro game fans.  One of the best games set in the Alien Universe period. I never played Colonial Marines, but I heard it was pretty bad.

The atmosphere was well done, the sound was great (especially in a nice set of headphones)
The art style, and music really added to the mood and lore of the franchise as a whole.
The graphics are nice, and the game ran smooth..
The gameplay was fun.  Intriguing, even some moments that scare/shock.
They did a great job with the Alien itself.
The progression, and equipment unlocks were fun enough to keep you wanting to actually search for more.

This stealth/hide cat and mouse game was done great in and of itself. But when you also have a game that does that, and does a great job with a well known franchise. Then you get something like Alien Isolation which was a great single player experience.

It is not a short game at all. It also has some DLC. (I only played the Last Survivor DLC. It was fun, about 30-40 minutes, but I didn't take my time in it like most of the main campaign) The main campaign was about 1.5 times longer than I expected it to be. I would of been happy if it ended a couple hours sooner. So many games now, and I have less time to enjoy them all.

I recommend playing it on Hard.

Play it in the dark, and loud. (in headphones if you have to)

Great refreshing gaming experience. Looking forward to more, especially once VR, or AR starts to get a stable foothold in gaming.

Frustrating and hard. No manual save option for the ultimate punishment (totally cool!). How to ninja something which was designed to hunt your kind down? It can see you even in total darkness. Hear your Steps and wither your Scent to find the right area. This is for Zen-Masters or very patient People only. Sometimes you will hide for minutes in the same place just to die and loose 10 minutes AGAIN.

A solid game experience with funny 80s References and the most perfect movie adaptation ever, concerning Lore, Setting, the areas and the Creature itself! The AI is an unholy Masterpiece.

13/10 In Space even your Dojo hears you scream! Your Neighbours will hate this game! There is no reward, no peace of mind. Just Frustration, Punishment and a neverending Tension.

Not recommended for KIds. Screw the Violence, but there is no reward here. Just Frustration! 13/10

reviewText:
My opinion of Alien: Isolation has radically changed over the course playing this game and, sadly, it wasn't at the very end when I liked it the most; I honestly thought it was gradually getting worse and worse. But even though A:I left a little bit of a bad taste in my mouth at the end, I would recomment it, because it just gets so many things right.
First of all, designs. This game in terms of aethetics is a period piece of an era that never existed. The 1970s and 80s' version of the the future was recreated with such immense detail that it makes for one of the most cohehise and convincing sci-fi worlds in a game that I have ever seen. Visually this game had me hooked from start to finish, as even at later stages I took my time to just look around the enviromnents to appriaciate the great effort that went into making it so authentic. Interestingly, this design language also translated to the look of UI, which has its retro-touches here and there like VHS-like artefacts and filmgrain. The radial menu plays into that aethetic, but it does so sadly at a cost of being a little unintuitive.  It was great to look at, but not so great to use.
Stealth mechanics were very well designed: sound effects provided very organic feedback, level design and crafting system worked hand in hand with keeping the player on the edge with just enough recources for distraction and  repulsion as well as enviromental advantages to get from point A to B. It takes a skillful approach and good use of all of the mechanics to avoid being horribly murdered over and over again.
The problem is that this game is long. Far too long for a horror game to work. I had so much time to get aquianted with the Alien's AI and strategies of survival that by the time I was about to finish this game, Alien has become more of an annoyence than a source of horror. Early encounters with the Alien counted among the scariest experiences I've had in a game, the later ones were unfortunetely completely devoid of tension; the effect was further emphesised by the introduction of a flamethrower, which basically made the Alien feel like a noisy little dog that you have to occasionally shoo away in order to move on. (NOTE: I don't mean to say that I use flamethrowers to shoo away dogs IRL)
It doesn't help that almost all of the objectives troughout the whole 12-20 hours long campaign revolve around tuning stuff on. Turn on the generator here, open doors here, go back to that place to get a key to other doors, turn on other generator to open these doors and so on and so forth. The constant tinkering and engineering was justified by the occupation of the protagonist but it didn't make it any lesss dull to me. Aside from that, the story seemed like it was poorly tacked on on top of ready-made setpieces. Amanda didn't seem like a fleshed out character in any shape or form, and the other character I couldn't care less about either. The half-♥♥♥♥♥ attempt at a plot twist in the last act was so poorly executed that it was kind of impressive.
I might sound like I hate this game, but all the bad stuff can be almost exclusively attributed to length, especially last few hours, so while I thought the ending was terrible, the first  3/4 of the game provide with a good enough experience to recommend it, especially if it's on sale.
+ perfectly captures the mood of the first movie
+ cool-as-balls retrofuturistic designs
+ great level design
+ Alien encounters are genuinely scary
+ gorgeous UI
- not necesesarily practical UI (radial and crafting menus are a little wonky)
- the story felt tacked on on top of already made up setpieces
- repetetive objectives
- TOO LONG

reviewText:
Alien: Isolation. Where do I even start? This game is hands-down a wonderful experience. The pros are great but the cons are plentiful, so I suppose I'll just hop right in.

Pros:
-This game is horrifying right off the bat.
-This game pays a lot of homage to the original movies (e.g. the futuristic 80's experience)
-The setting is very movie-accurate
-Lots of in-game mechanics are very unique and I've never seen before.
-Lighting was gorgeous
-The music/sounds are wonderful and really enhance gameplay
-This game made me shriek multiple times
-You're always terrified of the Alien

Cons:
-This game is based in two parts: before flamethrower and after flamethrower
-You're only terrified of the Alien until you get the flamethrower to make it go back from whence it came, quickly turning this game from a survival horror to an FPS
-(at least for me) the lip sync was terrible in cutscenes.
-Too many times the game pulls the classic You're safe now- OH WAIT! No you're not!"
-The Alien turns from being the main antagonist to just a general nuisance half way through the game
-Most of the characters I didn't care about at all
-Plot points were very predictable
-Ending was very
date:
very weak.
-Ripley never asked the all-important question: "Why the hell am I doing everything alone??"

It does seem that the cons outweigh the pros by a land slide
recommended: but after it's all said and done
hoursPlayed: I'm very happy that I played this game. I did enjoy playing it
voteText: I highly recommend it
helpfulPercent: but I don't think it was worth all the hype. My advice is to wait for this game to go on sale
votesHelpful: it was most definitely worth the $12.50 I paid
votesTotal: but I can't imagine it's worth $50."

reviewText:
Superb game, impressive graphics, atmosphere and details recreated perfectly, with engaging gameplay and very good story.

The Season pass is not worth it though, it is just a bunch of survival mode maps  that get old really fast, and the mechanics that worked well in the main game, are a hindrance to that mode, since you have a time competition with time limited objectives that are gamey elements that break the immersion. The fact that the alien always knows your general location doesnt help, that works in the main game, but not in this mode.

I finished the game with a great aftertaste, absolutely loved it, and yet, when I got to play the survivor mode, I barely completed 2 maps before uninstalling, it really is not fun and the game should have just stayed as a story driven one.

The other two DLC, last survivor and crew expendable are OK, though they are very short, so get them on a cheap sale, but DON'T get the season pass.

reviewText:
Forget Aliens Colonial Marines, and make way for a masterfully terrifying game called Alien Isolation.

Alien Isolation did the impossible, which made the Alien scary again. The Alien series is it's my favorite sci-fi movie franchise of all time. Alien Isolation recreated and captured the dark atmosphere of Ridley Scotts Alien film almost perfectly, which is shockingly awesome. This was by far the most terrifying Alien game ever made, the best Alien game to come out since the 1999 AVP Classic. If you enjoy survival horror and have a love for the Alien franchise like me this is your game.

Sorry to say though the ending was anticlimactic, and sometimes the Alien can ♥♥♥♥ you off. So there for it won't receive a perfect score.

9/10

reviewText:
Alien: Isolation will leave you scarred for life.
Wear these scars with pride.

PROS:

+ the presentation(stunning visuals and masterfully crafted audio)
+ constant fear and paranoia
+ intelligently used source material
+ the !@#$ ALIEN

CONS:

- some objectives during certain missions are counter-intuitive and will leave you walking in circles
- if you are an impatient player, get ready for some discouragement
- may be too nerve wracking for some

♥♥♥♥. This game. This mother♥♥♥♥ing piece of art.
The haunting sounds of Sevastopol will make your skin crawl.
The forewarning beeping of the motion tracker will sabotage your sense of security.
The titular Alien will tear your peace of mind to shreds.
During a circa 20 hour long campaign you will experience fear and terror redefined.
A:I has a strong cinematic feel to it.
The crafting system is neat and easy to use, allowing you to create tools and equipment which'll boost your confidence..for a minute or so.
Judging by the global achievements statistics, only 16 out of 100 people have actually made it to the end.
Be one of the 16.
You will not regret it.

This is Ripley

reviewText:
If you like the first two movies of the Aliens series you will probably enjoy Alien: Isolation.  It's basically a good game, with a lot of flaws.


The Good:

The plot is almost as good as the first two movies.

The graphics are great!  They look exactly like what you saw in the first two movies, only there is far more of it, and more variety.

The sound is also great!  The soundtrack, which seems to be wholly original, would be at home in the first two movies.  Many sound effects are taken from the first two movies, though new, fitting, ones are introduced.

The save points are reasonably distributed and implemented acceptably.

All the settings PC gamers expect are provided.


The Bad:

The reason the plot is almost as good as the first two movies is large swaths of it are copied from the first two movies.  This game could have benefited greatly from more creative writing.

The reason the plot is almost as good as the first two movies is it is too long and has too much filler.  When a movie in the Aliens series, or a video game, ends, it is usually on a note of success.  You never get that feeling of success in this game.  First you try Plan A, but that doesn't work…  Then you try Plan B, and that doesn't work either…  On and on until you run out of letters…  A good horror movie has at most 2 or 3 ‘plans’.  It's not that I wanted ‘less game’, it's that I want ‘more success per failure’.

Remember Amanda Ripley is supposed to be an engineer.  She should be rather intelligent.  The plot is very much ‘on rails’, and forces you (her) to do some really stupid things.  When Ripley encounters a barricade she never seems to question why it is there, or what could go wrong if she removes it.  She never constructs barricades (or anything but consumables) herself.  If these situations were going to arise in the game, it should have been for optional loot, and occasionally have had bad outcomes.

The plot also makes the opposite error.  Apparently Amanda Ripley is a master of all fields of study!  The game will tell you to <lingo> the <lingo>, and Ripley immediately understands this.  The poor player gets a circle on the map (which may be quite large, and refer to any floor), where they are expected to bumble around for an hour or three while being repeatedly killed by aliens before they understand what they are expected to do.  To further aggravate this problem, many interactive items are not obviously interactive.  For example, the first time you encounter a rats nest of blue pipes you will probably ignore it as more setting-appropriate clutter, especially since it has no gadgetry attached and doesn't highlight when you look directly at it, but no, that's interactive!

If you are at all technically-minded, you may be bothered by the fact that a lot of the setting makes no sense:
There is contrived ductwork everywhere.  Clearly in the future there are laws to assure space ships and space stations are accessible to alien parasites.  In Mission 12: Synthetic Solution, in the android dealer's back office, a room with a high ceiling, there is an undamaged duct that runs from the center of the ceiling to about six feet off the floor, specially engineered for alien convenience.
The law does not discriminate against Peeping Toms in the future.  There are easy to see through gratings placed on ductwork for your convenience.  They only appear in rooms where plot exposition occurs, like the one you observe Samuels through in Mission 12: Synthetic Solution.
There are doors everywhere with covers that have to be removed with a cutting torch.  So the engineers were smart enough to recognize that someone might need to be able to unlock the door from the other side, but they were not smart enough to think of more reasonable ways to allow that, like master keycards.
Alien: Isolation observes the tradition of including hacking minigames no one enjoys, but everyone feels obligated to include in their games.  As usual, the hacking minigames do not remotely resemble real hacking, and aren't even intellectually demanding.  They only require you react quickly enough.  On the bright side, they are easy and short, so you can quickly get back to more enjoyable parts of the game.
In Mission 16: Transmission, there is a computer displaying satellite coordinates against the left side of a device for inputting satellite coordinates.  Apparently in the future interstellar space flight is possible, but automating the entry of satellite coordinates is too complex.
In Mission 18: Tomorrow, Together, there are transit cars flying along rails that are broken every few feet, through tunnels that have collapsed.
The ending is terrible.  It is both short and unsatisfying.

The designers went for cheap hits and jump scares, instead of the slower-building atmospheric horror of the movies on which this game is based.  The game is worse for that.  Playing it involves a lot of trial and error.

The aliens are too omnipresent.  They quickly change from being scary to annoying.  They frequently rapidly cycle through their patrol route, and the difficulty isn't in figuring out how to sneak past them, but doing it in the narrow time window you are given.  They also linger in the area they think you are in for ages, so you spend lots of time rolling your eyes and sighing in some locker, waiting for them to move on so you can make some progress.

The alien AI is too limited and mechanical.  This might have gone unnoticed if it were not a constant pest.  Soon the player learns that the alien is always in their local area, and will cycle through its patrol route unless it sees or hears them or a distraction.  When it sees or hears them or a distraction it will linger in that area until it sees or hears something else of interest, gets bored and returns to its patrol route, or finds the player.  It will only ever pass through ceiling vents unless it can see the player through a wall or floor vent opening.  Its attack always consists of running straight at the player, even if there is a lit flamethrower pointed at it.  At that point any feeling of being hunted is lost.  They should have made the aliens behave more organically, but kept it fair by having them telegraph their actions, making it possible to escape them after you have been spotted, and giving the player vantage points to observe them.

Apparently the designers think that if a decaying space station was infested with lethal alien parasites, 99% of the populace would turn into sociopathic idiots.  They will start shooting at you on sight while screaming, “It didn't have to be this way!”.  The game provides no way to interact with them.  You aren't allowed to say, “I've got no interest in your food or equipment, and gunfire will just attract the creature, so can I please just pass by you to use that elevator?”  Instead you either have to kill them yourself and attract the alien, or use a noisemaker to attract the alien to have it kill them for you.  In other words, you have to act like a sociopathic idiot.

The cleanroom suits some androids wear should not grant them the ridiculous protection it does.  It makes sense that it stops the stun baton, but it shouldn't do anything to protect them from a pipe bomb going off directly under their feet, or similar catastrophic damage.

It would have been more believable if adult aliens could be killed.  It should be difficult, and ammunition should remain limited.

There are many annoying quick time events in this game.  There is usually no time pressure, no decision to make, and no way to mess them up.  It just made the cinema scenes have awkward pauses and clutter over them, and felt like busywork.

reviewText:
Alien: Isolation je akční horrorová survival hra z pohledu první osoby inspirovaná filmy s Vetřelecem. Převážně se odehrává na stanici Sevastopol kde se vše jaksi zkazí a musíte se dostat pryč. K tomu všemu vás nahání vetřelec. O tom to je v kostce, teď tedy k názorům...

Hra je naprosto úžásná. Už po prvním setkání s vetřelcem jsem věděl že toto bude dramatická zkušenost která vejde do mého top listu her. Příběh vás vtáhne, postavy jsou zajímavé a hlavně, atmosféra, ta je naprosto úžásná. Je dechberoucí jak strašně moc připomíná filmy a jak děsně vývojáři dokázali převzít svět filmů Vetřelec do hry. Už jen ta grafika a prostředí z toho dělá něco na co jen tak nezapomenete.

//Příběh
Jak jsem říkal v intru. Příběh se točí kolem stanice Sevastopol na kterou vy, tedy Ripley, se svojí skupinou přistanete, ale zjišťujete že nic není normální a Sevastopol je celý nefunkční a později i odhalíte děsivou pravdu, že za vše může tajemné stvoření z vesmíru. V podstatě celou hru se budete pohybovat na Sevastopolu a ve vyjímečných chvilkách na jiných lodích ale také budete i ve vesmíru na spravovatelských cestách když bych to tak řekl.Příběh vás dokáže vtáhnout a má zajímavé charaktery. Některé pasáže jsou velmi nezapomenutelné, budu se avšak vyhýbat spoilerům takže to by bylo k příběhu vše.

//Grafika
Tam není co dodávat. Je perfektní, bez chyby. Atmosféra je jak vystřihnutá z filmu, efekty a světla jsou úžasný a celkové zpracování má ten vetřelecký nádech.

//Ovládání
Ovládání mi přišlo na survival horror docela unikátní. Nebylo úplně klasické, neřekl bych že to byla novinka, ale mírně to v pár aspektech odbočilo od konkurentů. (Např. Naklánění funguje pomocí C a pohybových kláves. Mezerníkem neskáčete, místo toho vytasíte Motion tracker a pár další maličkostí.)
Celkově se ale dalo dobře zvyknout a ovládat, vše fungovalo jak má a bylo to pohodlné.

//Optimalizace
Optimalizaci jsem vždy chápal jako důležitou část hry, protože když vyrobíte skvělou hru, ale špatně je optimalizujete tak že jí nikdo nespustí, je to škoda. Naštěstí to není případ AI. AI jelo dobře, nesekalo se a vše fungovalo tak jak má!

//Dodatky
Hra slibovala nepředvídatelného vetřelce, no, dočinila slibu. Občas vám vetřelec připadá naprosto hloupý a vy se mu smějete jak si vás nevšiml ikdyž jste těsně vedle a někdy zas jste tři metry daleko a on si k vám doběhne a propíchne vás. To se mi velmi líbí protože to dodává hře ten pocit že jste neustále v nebezpečí a pravý přeživší, se krčí celou hru. Vetřelec je poměrně citlivý na zvuk, takže začnete sprintovat a pokud je poblíž už jste víceméně mrtvý.

Crafting system je jednoduchej a zábavnej. Můžete si vyrábět udělátka jako flashbangy, noisemakery a takové ty pomůcky k přežití. Naštěstí nemůžete kraftit náboje, to by bylo příliš op. Suroviny jsou po celém Sevastopolu takže prozkomávání se vám jistě vyplatí!

~~~~~
To bude asi zatím vše co mám v hlavě. Tato hra je 100% nejlepší Alien hra která kdy byla doposud vyrobená. Podle mě předčila AvP (2010) i AvP Classic a Colonial Marines...o tom se asi nemusíme bavit.

10/10  - Jedna z TOP Survival horror her které kdy byly vyrobeny.

crafting items and improvising when the alien is dangerously close.
