reviewText:
A tense and gripping Survival Horror with outstanding atmosphere.

Play as Amanda Ripley - Ellen Ripley's daughter, in a frantic survival for your life aboard the Nostromo as you sturggle to retrace your mothers footsteps.

This game is inspired by Ridley Scott's original iconic vision: There is only one Xenomorph to stalk you through the corridors. It is attracted to sound, so be mindful of your actions. There are plenty of other obstacles to face, whether it be maintenance failures, destroyed walkways, or frenzied androids, you will not have much down time.

The mechanics are simple and gratifying, with a button to sprint, sneak, hide and equip items/weapons. You are given many different instruments to utilize aboard the ship, including the iconic scanner. You can also craft items and equipment by collecting the needed materials and blueprints.

If you dig the first-person immersion, and prefer stealth oriented survival horrors over shoot-fest survival horrors, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Scary scary game!  I'm a huge Alien Universe fan, and I felt this game is probably the best one made for that universe.  There were some nit-picks I would have with it including unrealistic human interations (why does everyone want to kill me?) and some bits of the story are a little far fetch, plus I found the ending to be slightly predictable.

That said, the visuals are amazing, the alien is random and incredibly deadly, the game offers a solid challenge (hard mode), and it's the closest I think any of us will get to being in the alien universe.  The controls are solid, the sounds are amazing and terrifying, and the music engine plays all the right pieces at all the right times - adding significantly to the dark, isolated atmosphere.  The weapons add just the right balance of play without making you feel unstoppable.  The minute-to-minute decisions you choose yield consequences that matter for survival.  A great amount of detail went into the alien, as well.  Though some design and sound decisions for the alien I felt were'nt quite right, the creature as a whole is daunting and terrifying. It also has hidden Oculus Rift DK2 support that can be enabled from the configuration file which adds even more immersion to the universe if you have a Rift.

This is probably the strongest game in the sci-fi survival horror genre, and it's worth picking up if you are into that kind of thing (which I am!).  I've never been so happy to be hunted by the scariest creature in the universe!

P.S. - This is locker hiding simulator 2014 for gamers who are easily scared :)

reviewText:
Yes, the game certainly has its frustrating moments, I agree that the Alien can be unfair at times and me personally I would have loved to see some Coop or Versus-Gameplay.

But all critics aside.
One should appreciate Alien: Isolation for what it is: An amazingly well done resurrection of the franchise, after the somewhat mediocre AvP (2010) and the infamous Colonial Marines (2013) almost brought upon its own demise. Alien: Isolation certainly is the best Alien game since Aliens vs Predators II (2001) and I'm looking forward to seeing what they do with this new type of Alien games. I demand more and I'm not talking of DLCs!

reviewText:
SO far Alien: Isolation has been an awesome purchase. The atmosphere and sound design are really spot on, this studio really nailed it!
I finally have a really quality Alien franchise game in my library.
The graphics are nice and come with plenty of options in the menu, controls are fluid standard fare for most FPS.
Within the first minutes I got into the feeling of the first movie and the slow build up really made for a nice touch, since most games try to throw you into action right off the bat.

It seems like the Alien is learning and the difficulty feels really good. Every thing you do has you wanting to look over your shoulder and even saving takes a second leaving you exposed. No check points here, so if you forgot to save you will really have to go back.
What ever small flaw exists within this game is overshadowed by the awesome atmosphere and tension/stress you experience aboard the station/ship.

I only have minutes in crew expendable but it is freaky and looks to be really awesome. I can't wait to dive in further and more missions to come out.

This runs flawless on Ultra using;
AMD FX 8350 4.2GHz
8gb ddr3 ram
4gb 760 GTX windforce 3
The temperature of the card sits at 50c in game play and only in the options or alt tabbed it climbs to 56c. SO really cool in game.
Solid 60 fps and no problems to report so far.

reviewText:
If I could choose, which monster has scared me most ever since my childhood to this very day, you would probably guess either a vampire, a zombie or a bogeyman. But even combined they're nothing when compared to late Swiss artist H.R. Giger's most popular creation: the Alien. Ever since it was seen for the first time back in 1979, success followed on many fronts for a while. But unfortunately, nothing lasts forever. Rebellion (the very team that created two legendary AvP games back in 90's) tried to give us just as tasteful experience in 2010, but the time seemed to have passed the British team.

Still that wasn't even half bad compared to Aliens: Colonial Marines, the game that still gives me (and surely many other Alien -fans) a painful headache. Almost everything from the very core of the game was just messed up and instead of feeling fear, I just felt a shared sense of shame due to wasted potential. But when every last bit of Marine's equipment - even the iconic pulse rifle - is taken from you, what's going to happen then?

Creative Assembly's - British dev team known from Total War series - Alien: Isolation is anything but the same we've seen so many times: instead of being marine equipped with heavy firepower, you're pitted as a civilian, who lacks combat experience and who can be killed at any time. Literally. In Isolation you fight against your threats (mostly) by good thinking, not by guns. And that's just the beginning.

Isolation takes place 15 years after the events of Alien; commercial starship USCSS Nostromo has disappeared and so has  the game's protagonist's (Amanda Ripley) mother, Ellen Ripley. One day a man named Samuels comes to tell her that Sevastopol Station has acquired Nostromo's flight recorder and it doesn't take too much from him to convince Amanda to join retrieval team. Unfortunately things aboard Sevastopol Station aren't going well: humans turn on each other and shoot each other due to paranoia, mannequinlike Working Joe -androids have lost it and they attack humans at sight and last but not least there's an unstoppable, merciless alien roaming around the station.

Sevastopol Station is plainly put gorgeous and Creative Assembly has put the source material to a good use. Everywhere  you see something that reminds you of that time when the future wasn't so high-tech like it is shown in modern sci-fi series. Just add into this an atmospheric soundtrack, that has taken some notes from Jerry Goldsmith's composition and you're at home, especially if you're a die-hard Alien fan. But moving around Sevastopol isn't just exploring, because at the moment you either hear thumping or hissing nearby, you really wish that you knew the environment well enough to escape from the clutches of your enemies.

The mission pattern however is quite simple: most of the time you pull levers, hack the doors with your hacking tool and search for the component X to make it to the next level. But it's all about that nightmarish hide-and-seek -game between life and death that either encourages or discourages you to play the game through. Word of warning: Isolation is not a fun game, but I still like it very much. Why? Because it actually forces you to think even insignificant things through and through. Even the use of a safe system needs to be timed carefully, because when you're saving your progress, you're leaving yourself open to attack. Thus the fear of death is constantly present, especially in the first half of the game.

You're not completely helpless against the enemies, because with a motion tracker you can see their nearby location. As you progress, you'll find blueprints for different kinds of tools, such as EMP mines, noisemakers, smoke bombs etc. Every tool has its strengths and weaknesses, but you shouldn't rely on them too much, if you want to conserve your resources for real nasty situations. Firearms should be forbidden from use most of the time, because the sound of firing attracts unwanted attention and really, that's the last thing you want to do in this game. You can take down both humans and androids with guns, but stopping the alien itself requires either flamethrower, Molotov or pipe bomb, and even then it disappears only for a while.

Alien: Isolation, however, isn't a perfect game. In addition to monotonic mission pattern environments are recycled, especially on the last third of the game. And even though it took me almost 20 hours to complete the game, it would have actually taken 12(!) hours, showing that seemingly little mistakes have a huge impact on the game's events. To be honest, most of the time the fault was mine, because I either let my guard down or didn't pay enough attention to the environment. When I played this game second time on Nightmare -difficulty, only then I felt that some deaths were unfair, like when the alien jumped on me straight out of the vent without a single warning sign.

The game also has a Survivor mode, where you simply try to reach your destination, either as fast as possible or trying to get a good score by completing side objectives during the run. Alien and other enemies, of course, try to put a stop to your plans and you need to either outsmart or get rid of them faster than in the main game, provided you have enough resources to deal with them. Even though I find this mode interesting, with the main game there's only just ONE map and you're not probably going to spend much time with it, unless... you'll buy the DLC (*sigh*).

Anyways, I can say that Alien has finally got the game it truly deserves. The one that respects its source material and it keeps thrill-seeking players in its tight, even sadistic grip all the way through to the credits. Look out, necromorphs and other monsters from outer space, Daddy's come home!


PROS:
+ Late 70's sci-fi
+ Alien scares once again
+ Great environments...
+ Superb visuals and fantastic soundscape
+ Appropriately challenging

CONS:
- Mission pattern could have been more diverse
(- May frustrate you at times)
- ... that end up victims of recycling at the last third of the game
- Survivor mode (without the DLC packs) feels an empty addition


GRAPHICS:              9
SOUND:                  10
GAMEPLAY:            8
LASTING APPEAL:  8


FINAL VERDICT: 9

reviewText:
A slow paced progression horror survival game in the eerie and isolated Sevastepol space station. Alien: Isolation seems to be quite overrated because of the convincingly amazing graphics and the subject matter, but I feel like many of its flaws are being forgiven and ignored which doesn't do the developers and the players justice, and the genre indirectly suffers as a whole. It's important to note that there are people who just wont like this title.

Overall though, Alien: Isolation is worth experiencing for anyone who wants to explore the incredibly detailed space station, and while the story matter isn't going to satisfy the hardcore movie fans, it's fairly well done and treats James Carmons' works with respect. Anyone looking for a convincing atmosphere and genuinely scary gameplay from a horror game is also going to want to dive right in.

If you belong to neither group, then reviewing the pros and cons should help you decide whether this should go at the top or bottom of your priorities list. Either way it's worth a committed play through for most gamers.

Highlights
The setting for this game is absolutely great and the 80s product design, and detail on some of the rooms and appliances is incredible, especially early on. The mechanics and feel of the controls, when combined with the wonderful U.I. layers and concepts all add to the immersion and survival experience. The graphics and lighting too, have clearly had a lot of love and attention. It's also technically very sound, and despite a few object rendering glitches, the game as a whole feels very sturdy and reliable.

* Lighting is especially atmospheric and even beautiful in this game. At key moments in the main story you'll slowly become subtly more anxious through a combination of lighting, sound and design, only to have something startling occur, highlighted or hidden in the right way by the positioning of light in the room

Mistakes
The problems from this title all stem from the manner in which gameplay has been designed to fit into the world rather than the other way around. The developers have clearly either started with an amazing and detailed Sevastopol, or had an unrelenting focus on it throughout design, which has benefited the game by creating very real feeling exploration and
discovery while working through the game, but has also detracted from the gameplay in small ways.

Gameplay is often quite predictable after a point, and you know what's going to happen next based on simply the room design or text logs and the game pulls the old movie cliche of You've reached this point
date: now you're safe.. No you're NOT!" which wears thin. The plot too

reviewText:
Fantastic game!  Diapers not included.  9.7/10

I'm editing this review to override my initial somewhat-troll review, because I feel the need to express all my opinions about this wonderful game.  Also changed rating from a 9.0 to a 9.7  :)

Alien: Isolation is one of the best games I have ever played.  There.  I said it.  It is undeniably one of the most horrifying and scariest games of hide 'n seek you will ever play, and it hits home for Alien lore fans such as myself.

You play as Amanda Ripley, daughter of Ellen Ripley (Sigourney Weaver), who is an aerospace engineer that has received a job to do at the Sevastapol space station, with added hopes of finding what happened to her mother aboard the lost ship, the Nostromo.

Without going through spoilers, you traverse through what seems like a peaceful, yet unmaintained, space station, when things just keep breaking down and getting worse.  There are multiple threats you will encounter throughout the game, all of which you need to act accordingly.  You will sometimes be faced with the thought that you will have to SHOOT your way out of things, or simply run away--but that is NOT always the best option, as you-know-who will likely be hunting you.  And ohhh **** is it scary.  If and when you need to hide, Amanda has many gadgets she can craft using random materials she finds aboard the station--flashbangs, smoke grenades, noisemakers, are just a few of them--or she can simply hide under desks, in lockers, behind hard corners, etc.  When all else fails, there is a trusty weapon she can acquire (again, no spoilers) that she used in the movie.

This game is a very, very long game for an adventure horror game, and even at the easiest difficulty, your first playthrough will take nearly 20 hours, or possibly a lot longer.  Although replaying the game serves no purpose for the storyline, it can be fun (and stressful) to play through it again (and again) for achievements and/or collectibles.   As for lore purposes, the technology and environment is absolutely IDENTICAL to the movies, with the low-tech futuristic feel of what they use in space.

I changed my rating from a 9.0 to a 9.7 for a very specific reason:  this game just keeps getting better.  It is a game I absolutely hate to love because of how terrifying it is.  I've played through this three times so far, and I honestly keep eyeing it to come back for more.  It is worth every penny.  For people who are survival horror game fanatics--BUY THIS GAME--it is the BEST in the genre.  For everyone else, buy it and face your fears anyway.

Also, I wasn't lying about my first statement.  It doesn't come with diapers.  That's the only reason I didn't score this a 10/10.  Go buy them, you will need them.

reviewText: This game blew my mind. It played on all of my greatest fears of childhood and pit me against one of the biggest nightmares I've ever experienced. When faced with the Alien you feel small and incomprehendably frail, a real panic filling your body when you are forced to go against your natural instinct to run. Crew Expendable was a blast from my past that sent chills down my spine as every second felt like it was going to be my last. The Working Joe's are a bit of an ♥♥♥ pain, but can grasp you in terrifying ways when an entire army is coming for your throat.\n\nIn my personal experience, this is everything the Alien franchise needed, both in graphical gorgeousness and terror making you feel like you are in the first movie all over again. Nothing beats the raw impossibility of this Alien. Great job.

reviewText:
Alien:Isolation is a brave game, considering what the average gamer demands today. As a spin-off of the first Alien movie, the space station in which the game takes place mixes futuristic technologies and 70s stuff, while the general atmosphere of anxiety and loneliness is very true to the movie and perfectly realized with an amazing light usage. Like a true survival you have no chance to win a fight against the alien. You have to hide, reducing the noise as much as possible and only rely on your crafting abilities to survive: running will be your last card to play against such a superior specimen. Sound effects are great, your hearing being the first sense helping to evaluate your moves.
The AI is the pearl of the game: the alien will hunt you and trick you in such ways that will test your nerves, because revealing yourself will mean certain death.
There isn't any single breath you can take in this struggle. The tension will be high and constant and eventually leads to make bad decisions.
This is such a clever game, wonderfully realized within a vivid ambientation: a game not only Alien fans should play.

93/100

reviewText:
Do NOT pay attention to Gamespot and IGN's reviews of this game (They rated this 6 and 5.9 respectively). If you are a fan of the Alien franchise, this is the PERFECT game to buy. The quality production makes this game almost feel like a film itself.

In this game you assume the role of Ripley's daughter that is trying to discover what happened to her mother. Ripley herself is a great design (she looks like she could be Sigourney Weaver's own daughter).

This game is great survival horror. It's chilling, suspenseful, but not absolutely terrifying like other horror games. There is a lot of stealth in this game and it will almost feel like you're improvising the entire time as you try to survive in the space station.

PLEASE SIT DOWN AND SOMEONE WILL ASSIST YOU" 10/10

http://youtu.be/_nH_KVSb0q8
First the graphics were good but not as impressive as I expected. For example I was surprised to see a 2D image of the space station in an opening sequence.
-----The cinematic music was faithful to the original films and was a very nice touch. There is a generous amount of ambience, which is something that is really important to me.
-----The alien death Sequences were intense. However being killed by the Alien just became routine because it killed me so much.
-----The game featured a lot of darkness I was very impressed by this. Lighting was a strong point.
-----The alien looked good, it moved very fluidly and was very convincing. It was nerve racking when it was Stomping around just centimetres away from my hiding spots. Detailed closeups of characters during dialogue and cutscenes also looked pretty good.
-----The Sci-Fi world was faithful to the original film and period. It was the ‘future of the 80’s’. I was very happy to see a retro style world which didn’t try to look cute or goofy. One of the most impressive yet slow and uneventful sections was the space-walk on the space station exterior. There were massive satellite dishes and the you could get a good view of the station’s colossal towers.

I had a very confused introduction to combat. I thought stealth would be the only solution to hostile encounters. I spent an hour or so of my time playing the game not making any progress until I figured this out.
-----Next thing, save stations sometimes didn’t seem to feature frequently enough or sometimes I would miss them completely. The autosave feature didn’t always work at logical points in the game. After dying which happened frequently, I could find myself losing 15 minutes or more of gameplay. Plus I often had to repeat tasks and uneventful sequences again and again which became tedious as cool as they were.
-----Being able to save manually at any time could have been used to avoid this. Many things which I had to repeat in the game just weren’t necessary. Meaning that I spent comparatively less time engaging in more interesting action
-----Gunplay is actually very jerky in this game. Guns are hard to use accurately and fire very slowly. You have no access to automatic weaponry at all. Most weapons are rudimentary or makeshift. You will not feel like a badass marine or one woman army. You are very vulnerable. This was a very strong aspect to the the gameplay experience

-----The Alien lurks in many sections of the game. You can’t kill it. But if it get’s a hold of you it will kill you instantly, and it did so to me frequently.
-----Some items will cause it to retreat for a short time. But your supplies are very limited. For the most part you must hide and sneak around it. Being able to duck under furniture was a very cool way to do this.
-----The alien’s movement patterns were very unpredictable. When it’s gone and I thought it was safe to come out, it would often re-appear suddenly and unexpectedly. Graphics aside the Alien A.I. was the best and most important feature of the game.
-----Dealing with the Alien was very challenging and intense. The section which first really featured the alien would only take a few minutes to walk through if it wasn’t present. However because of my frequent deaths it took me around an hour to get through. For this reason sometimes long sections featuring the Alien could actually become tiresome.
-----But there are occasionally stages where the Alien is not present. This was a welcome change of pace.
-----The other main adversaries are the working Joe androids. They are very tough. But they’re very slow and even large groups of them can be easily dispatched without taking a scratch. However they can be very unnerving if you’re in a confined area and several of them are converging on you.

It took me around 20 hours to complete Alien: Isolation in the hardest difficulty. I think that was too long. I would have been happier to get through the main storyline in only half that time. Because I feel that I often found myself in the same situation repeatedly only in different places.
-----Also the ending wasn’t conclusive. I don’t think any full game should end with what is essentially a teaser.
-----But I still enjoyed it overall. It’s an extremely impressive Alien game. It was really satisfying to have a game in the franchise that wasn’t a massive disappointment, it’s really done it justice.

Click here for my YouTube gaming channel

reviewText:
It's been a good long time since I played a game that scared me as bad as this masterpiece. Every playthrough being another nightmare, every encounter a new threat. Although, fair warning - Halfway through the game (That is, if you're sparing with flamethrower fuel) the game loses it's edge. Not that it's bad, just less terrifying, more tense.


From the locker you've been hiding in for the past hour, you finally hear nothing. You check your motion tracker - All good. Making an effort to pace yourself down the narrow hallways, you take time to plan your new route and note any hiding places. The last group of androids you stumbled upon costed you all of your gear, save for one molotov. After making it through several hallways, finding almost no useful supplies, you stop, hearing movement to your right. Below? No, whatever it is, it's above you. You swat your flashlight off, and dash under the nearest bed. Before you can even check your tracker again, something crashes into the ground next to you. An undescribable scream pierces the air, as if announcing how unsafe this area has now become. You can only see it's tail now, inches away from your feet.
Across from you lies the key to your escape, your survival, it is of a course, a vent.
The creature walks away, But you can hear it in the distance. Hunting. Under pressure, a decision must be made. Hide until it inevitably finds you, or make a break for the vent?
Trying your best not to gather it's attention, you dive into the vent.
You weren't fast enough.
It heard you.
It's coming.
Don't panic.
You aren't doomed.
You have one option.
The vent is opening.

THERE IT IS.

Hurling it as hard as you can, the molotov soars through the metal passageway.
With it's impact comes a sound of distress alike to none you've heard before.
As it storms off, you take this chance to crawl to your destination. Finally safe, you think to yourself. Strolling through the corridor with a new courage about you.

Unfortunately, this is the last thing you ever thought of before you made the mistake of walking under that vent.



10/10 would have a heart attack again, go pick it up y'wads.

reviewText:
A stunningly beautiful game, it captures the claustophobia of the original Alien movie beautifully and the levels give you the very strong feeling that you are there in Ridley Scott's original vision.
The sound is very good too.

Why the negative though? Honestly it is dull, there is no tension (not after seeing the Alien the first few times) because nothing breaks the tension of the game and the awesome experience of the space station as much as the Alien itself!

Thats right, the main protagonist is the least interesting part of the game.

If there was some sense of 'my' actions being the cause for the Xenomorph turning up and getting nasty. If there was a way to hide (in abject fear) whilst waiting for the Alien to get bored and go looking for space noms elsewhere it would work. But instead the Alien just 'lingers'. It is there and stomps around like your partner when they have had a bad day and are looking to get angry at you for some reason.

I found i was just as successful, and enjoyed the experience as much, just dying/loading instead of making the effort to hide too much. It felt like there was little point anyway.

reviewText:
Wow. This is a triumph in gaming. The reviewer who reviewed this from IGN doesn’t know his ♥♥♥♥ from his elbows. What an amazing game. Well, I say game. It’s not so much as a game as an experience. This is the Alien Experience and the true sequel to Ridley Scotts original vision. This game is a masterpiece in gaming history. It won’t be for everyone’s tastes, sure. This is the classic vintage; a glass of red wine, a tipple of single malt whiskey with a dash of tepid water served on chilled amazeballs.

For any fans of Ridley Scott’s first film this will allow you to live the nightmare … and it’s freakin awesome. It’s like playing a new Alien movie with a great plot, great actors, creepy henchmen, and an absolutely fantastic lead villain, oh and not to forget an absolutely wonderful little voice performance from the most awesome Sigourney Weaver. With just a moment she adds a touch of class to an already brilliant piece of Art.
Graphically stunning, the visual design was beautiful right from the very opening moments of inhabiting Ripley’s body. The lighting, the smoke effects, all the little attentions to detail thrust me right into Servastopol. It’s like wandering the sets of the original movie and it ran like a dream on my machine. I rarely find games that will run at top graphics and run well. This had no trouble at all. The optimization was spot on.

The opening Act was nothing short of Oscar worthy. By the end of it I had Ripley cowering in a corner and I had a smile on my face so big it hurt. I was terrified and loving it. The music just kept building and building and I found myself wanting to shout at that little f*&(#$ to stop toying with me and come get me. That experience alone was worth the price tag for the game. The rest was just icing on the cake. People have complained about the length. Fools. This game just keeps giving. And don’t be put off by one of the earlier levels. The designers switch it up during the game; they just give you a taste of the rough stuff early on to keep you on your toes throughout the rest of the ordeal, though I will admit, there was a point during this level where I thought to myself, ‘if it is like this for the rest of the game this won’t be a fun experience.’ Take heart, this is just a tough level.

And one cannot even begin to praise this game without first giving a nod and a tip of the hat to the sound design which is nothing short of spectacular. If Oscars were given to games the sound design for this game would most definitely win and be praised for years to come. Listening to that little f*&$%$ crawling around in the vents above you fills you with all the right emotions. The sound of the dying station creaking and moaning submerses you into the game world. The soundtrack immerses you into the world and builds at times in such a wonderful way it makes your heart thump all the louder.

The AI of the alien is excellent. During my time on Sevastopol I really felt like I was being hunted. Watching that creature from the shadows filled me with dread as it actually appeared to be trying to seek me out. I often felt like it knew I was there or, at least, that I had recently been there not long before. And sometimes I even felt like it was trying to trick me to come out of hiding just by the way it acted. I was hid under a table at one time and waited quite some time before plucking up the courage to head for the door, just mere meters from my position. At one point I watched on my sensor as the Alien raced off through the vents at great speed. I was about to come out when the little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ came racing right back and dropped from a nearby vent with a hiss.

As with any form of art opinions will differ. This will not be everyone’s cup of tea. But for those of you who love computer games for what they can do, what boundaries they can push, like the wonderful Half Life in its glory days. This is one of those games that will be remembered and not just for the amazing visuals, Oscar worthy sound design or even the most worthy AI of the exomorph hunting you, but also for the way it weaves the story. Telling story can be hard in games, especially first person shooters. This does it superbly. The link to the original movie is perfect for sucking you right into the universe. It is not a complicated story. It is simple and all it needs to be to experience the horror Ripley experiences on her journey to Savastopol. And what a journey it is.

There are so many little touches that I would love to share about the game but that would just serve to spoil. All I would say is, don’t read spoilers or how-to’s, and don’t watch play-throughs or walkthroughs. Go in knowing as little as possible. Throughout my play-through I was often pleasantly surprised at the twists this game took and the places it dared to tread through the Ripley Scott classic. I often found myself guessing seconds before and saying “Nooooooooo,” as I realized the horror the game was placing me in next.  But each time that smile would return as I would relish the beautiful sci-fi horror of it all. 10 out of freakin’ 10.

reviewText: SO! a public review shall we. as of writing this i havent gotten that far far enough that mister bruce is hunting me... bruce for those who dont know is an alien. for those who do know kinds of lights and dials knobs and levers its what you would expect from the alien universe. you play as amanda ripley sent to sevastopol to get some closure about your mothers disappearance "specifically a flight recorder" having the story set up you head out and soon after ariving things turn pear shaped preatty quickly and you will soon find yourself scavenging to survive and hoping to god that android/human/alien didnt just spot you behind that small crate you decided to hide behind. the ai is brutal even on normal where it will spot you even in preatty much pitch blackness and combat is even more ruthless as a few shots will do you in quickly if you are not careful. the game has a few drawbacks mainly quick time events "they are relatively rare however phew" as well as going back and forth multiple times in an area for things that could have been located at the same area. that being said this game is quite amazing not far in you will bite at your tongue in tenseness reviewText:
I could safe to say that Isolation will not disappoint hardcore Alien fans. Alien Isolation stays true to the original 1979 Alien flim in terms of technology, music, and artstyle while making it an terrifying, but graphically beautiful modern video game. Instead of being gung-ho and shooting aliens, you are defenseless against it and the best solution is avoid direct contact at all times and survive.

The alien in the game is brutal... you will have to keep your wits together and always keep an eye out for him and any possible escape routes and hidey holes in your surroundings in case things go sour. The alien will also try many ways tricking in getting you out from hiding spots when you're least expected so always keep looking your motion tracker and try not to keep it up too long otherwise it will hear your motion tracker beeping like a christmas tree. I won't spoil too much about the game, you will have to play it yourself and experience the horror.

I have finished the game including the DLC and my experience with the game has been awesome! I love it with a passion and glad the developers stick true to the original flim and inputting the survival horror aspect. I highly recommend this game to any Sci-Fi and Alien fans! I also dare you to play this game on Nightmare mode for the ultimate horror experience!

reviewText:
In Alien: Isolation you play as Amanda Ripley, as you try to find some closure about your mother's fate. You go to a remote free port space station called the Sevastopol, but you quickly realize that things went horribly wrong. As in the first movie, you only face a single Alien.

The Alien's AI is pretty solid, he will easily spot you if he has a direct line of sight. Running is risky, as he will hear you and he easily outruns you. Even inside a locker, he can hear you breathe and the vents aren't safer, as he uses them himself. The Alien also one-hit kills you. While is behavior isn't scripted, he will always be in your general area.

To help you, you are given a motion tracker, but as it does make a beeping noise, you must use it with caution. You also get a flamethrower, but ammo for it is very rare.

The Xenomorph isn't the only threat, as robots become aggressive against everyone and hostile human gangs form inside the space station. To add to the overall tension, there are no checkpoints, you can only manually save the game in phone booths scattered across the station, so dying can mean going back and redo a considerable portion of the game.

The graphics are outstanding with the lightning and steam effects perfectly fitting the theme. The retro futuristic style is perfectly nailed being in sync with the movies. The only negative part of the game for me was the ending, it largely hints a sequel or dlc and it doesn't give you any closure, and in a game where closure was so important, it ends up being a missed opportunity.

Alien: Isolation might be frustrating at times, as you will die... a lot, but the constant tension and thrilling story make it one of the best games of 2014!

reviewText: Never before have I played a game based off a movie with such good attention to detail. The game looks incredible to play and the story takes just the right amount of material from the movies to be part of the Alien franchise, but doesn't intrude too much into the movie lore so it's able to be it's own thing. It's frighteningly suspensful and I found myself constantly on the edge of my seat dreading what was coming next. And the sounds... oh, the sounds. Headphones are recommended, hell, even required to play this game. Every beep and creak adds to the immersion of life on a spaceship. Honestly it's my Game Of The Year despite a few glitches here and there, but it's dedication to the source material is truly astounding. Alien is meant to be horrifying and Alien Isolation captures that horror perfectly.\n\n10/10

reviewText: Alien: Isolation is easily the most ambitions, bold and uncompromising mainstream game of 2014. Instead of following the tropes of recent AAA games, the open world environment of the Sevastopol space station is not yours - it's the Xenomorphs hunting ground and you're just another living piece of food. And that lead to the mixed reviews it initially received: the game plays with you.\n\nThe game doesn't take you by the hand. Where other sneaky action games like Dishonored are power fantasies and present the players stealth abilities as a strength to overpower your enemies, hiding is your only option to survive. Alien: Isolation is extremely slow, it's repetitive (depending on how much you die) and it's unfair - and that's why I'm absolutely in love with it.

reviewText: Alien Isolation is enormously stressful to play. It is tense and exhilarating, but you would have a hell of a job describing it as fun. This is not a game for everyone. For maximum effect, play in a dark room with good headphones! Those that are looking for a convincing interpretation of sci-fi's most terrifying monster will be well-served. You can’t hurt it, you can’t run from it. All you can do is hide and prey it passes you by. So you get one methodical, unstoppable menace that stalks the space station Sevastopol, killing anything it comes across. When in sight, you can track it and do your damnedest to avoid it. What really flings heart into throat is when you don’t know where it is. Sometimes the game will feel tough. It is slow. It is brutal. It is uncompromising in its vision to make the alien the perfect killing machine. You will die, a lot! HR Giger’s Alien is a direct sequel and homage to Scott’s movie, it looks and feels every inch the video game blockbuster! 10/10

reviewText:
What a visceral, immersive experience! The buyer gets his money’s worth within the first few hours of this atmospheric Sci-Fi Horror game if racing heartbeat and sweaty palms are a measure. Mostly I play action or soldier games and usually I’m running into the action even if I have to replay an area several times to get to the next. But frustration is the dominant feeling in those games, not the dread and terror of creeping down a dimly lit corridor, all the while hearing bumping and thumping all around and above me (and the unsettling soundtrack) as the alien hunts for me. The squawky detector is a help to tell you when the alien is near but sometimes the random pips and scratches send a false alarm that need to be checked out.

Fans of the Alien series of movies will love wandering around the nearly-abandoned, deep-space manufacturing complex which truly captures the look and feel of the style in the movies. But it’s obvious that something went very wrong here, and it’s your job to explore where needed to fulfill the missions (rather than Chapters) as the game progresses.

The difficulty can be changed under Options but only within the game.  Game Save is only allowed at specific stations which means in some levels you have to redo many minutes of nerve-shattering creeping around only to get skewered again by “that thing”. So I recommend taking the time to slink back to the save station when mini-tasks are completed even when it’s out of your way and you’d rather not backtrack more than you have to.  Another minor complaint is the sometimes contrived reason you have to put yourself in harm’s way but that is just another convention of the genre.

There are many visual and auditory references to iconic games such as Half-Life and Portal (and probably others I miss). An earlier Alien game got terrible reviews due to hang-up and crashing problems but this one is a winner on par with these other benchmark games. If you don’t want to buy it at the reasonable market pricing at least put it on your Steam wishlist and buy it when you get the email that it’s on sale. That will limit your financial exposure, but nothing but heightened awareness and a fuelled-up flamethrower will protect you when you creep out of your hiding place to see what’s beyond the next sliding door…

(Here's a great trailer that shows players' reactions: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7EWe69vP1pA )

reviewText:
I like this game. I really do. I absolutely recommend getting this game when it's on sale (Even at a price of 40-50 dollars, this is still a solid buy for a 15-25 hour long campaign).  However, I have really mixed feelings about this game, similar to the reviewers who rated this game on Gamespot and IGN.  While I think their final verdict is wrong, I feel they had some good constructive criticism about certain aspects of this game that I feel are getting glossed over because of the anger of the scores they gave this game.  Therefore, I'm going to try to write something that will help skeptic buyers eying this game understand the difference between those reviewing this game on Steam and those reviewing this on IGN and Gamespot.

The main crux of this game is that this is simply not a game about closure.  If you are playing this game looking for a payoff, this is not your game.  The plot of the game (while brilliantly paced toward its first four or so hours) begins to deteriorate toward the middle of the game. It simply does not know how to end itself.  It also doesn’t help that the main cast of characters rank from developed but underused to undeveloped but overused. Do *not* play this game expecting Amanda Ripley’s personal journey of finding out what happened to her mother to be front and center in the narrative.  Frankly, by midway in the game, she’s just a shell for the player.  In short, this is not the type of game that is “fun” to play and isn't looking to reward" to its player upon its completion….which is why the reviewers at sites like IGN and Gamespot ultimately gave negative feedback concerning this game.

What this game is an Alien immersion simulator.  The art and audio teams behind this game did their homework on the Alien lore to perfection.  This is probably the only Alien game in existence to fully capture Ridley Scott’s universe and H.R. Giger’s terrifying vision of the Alien. Everything is there…the lightning
recommended: the retro technology….it’s all perfect.  I’m not going to retread what other reviewers have said about the gameplay.  It’s a great cat-and-mouse game that only gets interrupted by an abnormal difficulty spike in a medical ward and the game’s messy writing calling for an Alien-free section toward midway in the game.  Yes
hoursPlayed: it is frustrating
voteText: but the immersion factor keeps you playing.  If you are anything like me
helpfulPercent: you’ll be more connected to the complicated history of Sevastopol (told through the computer and audio logs of its residents) than you ever will be with the main characters of the game.\n\nThe best way I can summarize this game is that it captures everything about the original Alien movie *except* a cast of great characters and a sense of conclusion.  This is a game that only will ever truly seem to stop until you simply stop playing it.  This game is indeed a triumph for the Alien franchise
votesHelpful: but lacks the storytelling and sense of climax and closure the first Alien movie us.  It’s not a game you can replay to get served the same enjoyable meal again; it’s more like to experience the same mental high that will satisfy
votesTotal: but ultimately fade away and leave you burnt out until the next time you are ready to experience the terror of the Alien once more."

reviewText: If you enjoy atmospheric horror games, Alien: Isolation is amazing in that genre.  Developed to closely resemble Ridley Scott's Alien, this game bring the fear of being hunted by an unstoppable creature to the table.  The details and hidden throwbacks to the movie show the dedication of Creative Assembly when they made this awesome game.  This is my 2014 Game of the Year.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: No other creature in movies or other media haunted me so much as does the Alien.  Being exposed to the first movie at a very young age (5 or 6), that thing has given me nightmares even as an adult.  I have played pretty much any and all Alien game since.  But this one, this has me quivering in fear.\n\nI love it and hate it at the same time.  I love the atmosphere, I love the music and storyline (at least what I can play to) and the Alien is modeled and animated perfectly.  I hate that I don't have the stomach to play this.  Simply because the Alien (at least to me) is so very much alive and not a mindless pulse rifle fodder.  This is a childhood terror that has returned to me in adulthood and I thank good people at CA to finally make this game.  Anyone who loves the first Alien film must play this game.  Even if you never can complete it (I know I will, just need a lot more time). Just play it.

reviewText:
The taste of the first two Alien movies, and balanced like %75 Alien, %25 Aliens. Makes you watch the quadrilogy again.
Survival is balanced, yet you curse Mr. Alien a lot. Just when you think you are safe, they jump down from the nearest vent. Puzzles are fairly easy, and hiding from the alien is half patience and half luck. Sometimes you may load your game for an hour in hard modes.

Although being a console port, it looked well optimised for my midrange laptop. Never complained about performance on high gfx with no AA. Mouse lag is massive though, but you don't need to aim a lot like a shooter.

Just when you think game starts to be repetitive or boring, setting and main aspect changes and playing experience refreshens.

If you are even a remote Alien fan, not a die-hard one, this is a must buy game for you.
PS: Surround headset is a must for immersion.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An utterly incredibly well detailed reimagining of the original Alien movie in the form of a game, putting you at the forefront of an alien attack with no guarantee of survival.
Your only option? To hide from the creature, distract it, perhaps deter it...but if it catches sight of you...well, let's just say it doesn't really end well for you.
The only real issue with this game is that it tends to lose steam near the end of the game, which feels like it should have been an hour shorter than it actually was, especially considering the payoff was...not exactly great, to be honest.
However, the last bit aside, it is still a wonderfully constructed game deserving of the name of the most horrifying thing in space - Alien.

reviewText:
My cat loves to bother me when I play on the computer, often swishing his tail back and forth, gently brushing up against my leg as a subtle gesture to scratch his head. But.

Since I have my headphones cranked up when I play this, I can't hear my cat move and as I watch the Alien's tail swish and slide across the ground while I'm hiding under a desk, his tail brushed up against me, I screamed, scared off my cat and pooped a little.

This is the only game I have ever played where there has never been a breaking of immersion and the faithful recreation of such a specific time period and piece. Half the sounds of the space station I mistake for the alien breathing or scraping against walls or stomping around. Audio is my biggest topic in games and this one is absolutely perfect.

I don't care if it's long. It respects my intelligence and refuses to hold my hand. Use your brain! That's all you have to do.

235123/10, just uninstalled every single other game I own and will only play this for the rest of my life.

reviewText:
Update - i did kind of enjoy it in the end!


--------
I have spent a while playing this game so far and I would say most of it has been spent playing over the same bits several times due to being killed by the alien/androids.  Unfortunately due to the save points being pretty far apart at times this is starting to make the game rather repetitive and frustrating.

I guess the good points are:

The game has a great atmosphere.  The corridors of the Sevastopol look great and it really does feel like you are stuck on a space station.  The lighting effects and smoke combined with the creaking and groaning of the metal of the ship add to this greatly.
There is definitely a sense of tension, panic and urgency when playing. You don't really ever feel like you can relax after the first encounter with the Alien.  I spend the whole game crouched!
Nice use of logs to build the story but also the other NPCs add to the story - I wasn’t really expecting there to be other people in the game.  (Just Ripley and the Alien)

The Bad:
Seemingly random Alien attacks.  For realisms sake this makes sense but in the game it is just far too frustrating - at one point I was running to escape from someone and the alien grabbed me from an air vent above with no real warning.  Another time I was trying to make my way to a save point when it appeared behind me and tore me in two.  Whilst the deaths are mildly amusing the lack of frequent AutoSaves mean you have to go and play through large sections again.
The Stealth... sometimes it works well but other times it becomes almost too hard to stay hidden.  The motion tracker is more of a hidrence to this.  It would have been good to have some sort of indicator similar to the one used in Metro Last Light to let you know when you are visible.
The music - in the end I have turned this off.  It drowned out a lot of the noises you needed to hear and although it added to the tension it just became annoying.
As I have already mentioned the lack of save points.  There really needs to be save points when going between sections of the game.  I don’t always have that much time to spend playing a game so always appreciate the ability to save when you need to.  If the player wants to save every five minutes - let them....it doesn’t change the gameplay just removes some frustration.


I really do want to like this game and It has exceeded my expectations but they we set pretty low.... I think I could recommend it but I found that I enjoyed the much-slated Thief remake much more than this so far.

So if you haven’t bought thief.... maybe get that cheap until the price of this drops!

For now this is a not recommended - if an update changes something with the save points this may change.

**edited out typos**

reviewText:
Update - i did kind of enjoy it in the end!


--------
I have spent a while playing this game so far and I would say most of it has been spent playing over the same bits several times due to being killed by the alien/androids.  Unfortunately due to the save points being pretty far apart at times this is starting to make the game rather repetitive and frustrating.

I guess the good points are:

The game has a great atmosphere.  The corridors of the Sevastopol look great and it really does feel like you are stuck on a space station.  The lighting effects and smoke combined with the creaking and groaning of the metal of the ship add to this greatly.
There is definitely a sense of tension, panic and urgency when playing. You don't really ever feel like you can relax after the first encounter with the Alien.  I spend the whole game crouched!
Nice use of logs to build the story but also the other NPCs add to the story - I wasn’t really expecting there to be other people in the game.  (Just Ripley and the Alien)

The Bad:
Seemingly random Alien attacks.  For realisms sake this makes sense but in the game it is just far too frustrating - at one point I was running to escape from someone and the alien grabbed me from an air vent above with no real warning.  Another time I was trying to make my way to a save point when it appeared behind me and tore me in two.  Whilst the deaths are mildly amusing the lack of frequent AutoSaves mean you have to go and play through large sections again.
The Stealth... sometimes it works well but other times it becomes almost too hard to stay hidden.  The motion tracker is more of a hidrence to this.  It would have been good to have some sort of indicator similar to the one used in Metro Last Light to let you know when you are visible.
The music - in the end I have turned this off.  It drowned out a lot of the noises you needed to hear and although it added to the tension it just became annoying.
As I have already mentioned the lack of save points.  There really needs to be save points when going between sections of the game.  I don’t always have that much time to spend playing a game so always appreciate the ability to save when you need to.  If the player wants to save every five minutes - let them....it doesn’t change the gameplay just removes some frustration.


I really do want to like this game and It has exceeded my expectations but they we set pretty low.... I think I could recommend it but I found that I enjoyed the much-slated Thief remake much more than this so far.

So if you haven’t bought thief.... maybe get that cheap until the price of this drops!

For now this is a not recommended - if an update changes something with the save points this may change.

**edited out typos**

reviewText:
The taste of the first two Alien movies, and balanced like %75 Alien, %25 Aliens. Makes you watch the quadrilogy again.
Survival is balanced, yet you curse Mr. Alien a lot. Just when you think you are safe, they jump down from the nearest vent. Puzzles are fairly easy, and hiding from the alien is half patience and half luck. Sometimes you may load your game for an hour in hard modes.

Although being a console port, it looked well optimised for my midrange laptop. Never complained about performance on high gfx with no AA. Mouse lag is massive though, but you don't need to aim a lot like a shooter.

Just when you think game starts to be repetitive or boring, setting and main aspect changes and playing experience refreshens.

If you are even a remote Alien fan, not a die-hard one, this is a must buy game for you.
PS: Surround headset is a must for immersion.

reviewText:
An utterly incredibly well detailed reimagining of the original Alien movie in the form of a game, putting you at the forefront of an alien attack with no guarantee of survival.
Your only option? To hide from the creature, distract it, perhaps deter it...but if it catches sight of you...well, let's just say it doesn't really end well for you.
The only real issue with this game is that it tends to lose steam near the end of the game, which feels like it should have been an hour shorter than it actually was, especially considering the payoff was...not exactly great, to be honest.
However, the last bit aside, it is still a wonderfully constructed game deserving of the name of the most horrifying thing in space - Alien.

reviewText:
I must admit, when I first encountered this game, I was cautious. I love the idea of the Alien franchise, dabbled in sections of the movies, but, frankly, I'm a coward, and this game scared the absolute living ♥♥♥♥ out of me.

Now, you may say: Well, even for an Alien game, that's an overreaction

Well my good sir/madame, please follow these instructions:

Get a nice screen, computer, or TV, and make sure you can immerse yourself.
Wear decent quality earbuds/headphones, surround sound speakers recommended.

Turn off all of the lights

Then try to play the game, as an Alien hunts you down, and each tiny little creak of the deck, each tiny little crackle, ANY DAMN SOUND AT ALL IS MAGNIFIED BY 10 AS YOU RUN THE HELL OUT OF THERE!

You may notice I haven't played this game very much.

I can explain

This game terrifies me so much, I cannot play it for extended periods of time without risking mental damage or damage to  my electronics.

10/10, will play again, as soon as I've cleared things up with my psychologist.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't often do reviews, but I feel this game is deserving of my attention. This is the game we've all been waiting for, long expecting a game of intense atmosphere and horror for the Alien franchise. A game where we are no longer on equal fighting ground with the Alien but more-so at its mercy.

The game offers a brilliantly designed and crafted sturctural world of dark corridors, sparking lights, that eerie space station feel of vast emptiness and isolation and of course, one of our favourite creatures of all time: Alien. But alas Alien is not the only problem on the Space Station Sevastopol, other survivors and killer androids are also a thing to keep an eye out for as well as a variety of planning, strategy and careful timing to complete each objective you are faced with.

Graphics: 9/10
They did really well with the graphics and rendering of the space station itself as well as all the models of characters and Ai Controlled. The lighting of the game really helps to envelop you in the tense and dreary world you find yourself in for most of the game. Blood spatter, broken structural mainframe, the classic Sci-Fi feel of the original Alien world and even Alien drool, this was really well done and I loved it all.

Music: 10/10
We all know how music and sounds can affect the outcome of a game by either bringing its full potential to fruition or utterly destroying the feel of the game, the designers nailed this games music and sounds. From the Alien crawling around in the vents, to the sheer terror of a music buildup as an enemy approaches your hiding place, I personally think it affected the overall feel and atmosphere of the game and bought what I was hoping to be, to be even better than what I ahd expected.

Atmosphere: 10/10
The Atmosphere? Terrifying to say the least if you really put yourself in Amada's place and forget the outside world, lights off, surround sound, high graphics. The Atmosphere of the game is only as good as YOU want it to be and for me, it's an experience I won't soon forget. This game has one of the most strongest atmosphere's of horror and survival over any other game I've played

Gameplay: 9/10
Being difficult to see and keeping your flashlight off so you don't attract unwanted attention, the game offers a brilliant variety of stealth and distraction techniques you need to employ in order to progress through and to keep your body intact. The construction of in-game items plays a major role in easing your stealth tactics and giving you access to a variety of traps and distraction tools to use at will. Hiding and bypassing Humans, Androids and the Alien alike were all to my liking as I am a very cautious person in these sorts of games and am not hasty in my decision making.

Overall, if you want my advice for the most optimal experience for this game, turn off your lights, play alone in your room with a headset on, put the graphics as high as your PC can run them and play on the hardest difficulty like I did. This is just my opinion on what you should do though, you can decide what to do for yourself.

reviewText:
I like this game. I really do. I absolutely recommend getting this game when it's on sale (Even at a price of 40-50 dollars, this is still a solid buy for a 15-25 hour long campaign).  However, I have really mixed feelings about this game, similar to the reviewers who rated this game on Gamespot and IGN.  While I think their final verdict is wrong, I feel they had some good constructive criticism about certain aspects of this game that I feel are getting glossed over because of the anger of the scores they gave this game.  Therefore, I'm going to try to write something that will help skeptic buyers eying this game understand the difference between those reviewing this game on Steam and those reviewing this on IGN and Gamespot.

The main crux of this game is that this is simply not a game about closure.  If you are playing this game looking for a payoff, this is not your game.  The plot of the game (while brilliantly paced toward its first four or so hours) begins to deteriorate toward the middle of the game. It simply does not know how to end itself.  It also doesn’t help that the main cast of characters rank from developed but underused to undeveloped but overused. Do *not* play this game expecting Amanda Ripley’s personal journey of finding out what happened to her mother to be front and center in the narrative.  Frankly, by midway in the game, she’s just a shell for the player.  In short, this is not the type of game that is “fun” to play and isn't looking to reward" to its player upon its completion….which is why the reviewers at sites like IGN and Gamespot ultimately gave negative feedback concerning this game.

What this game is an Alien immersion simulator.  The art and audio teams behind this game did their homework on the Alien lore to perfection.  This is probably the only Alien game in existence to fully capture Ridley Scott’s universe and H.R. Giger’s terrifying vision of the Alien. Everything is there…the lightning
recommended: the retro technology….it’s all perfect.  I’m not going to retread what other reviewers have said about the gameplay.  It’s a great cat-and-mouse game that only gets interrupted by an abnormal difficulty spike in a medical ward and the game’s messy writing calling for an Alien-free section toward midway in the game.  Yes
hoursPlayed: it is frustrating
voteText: but the immersion factor keeps you playing.  If you are anything like me
helpfulPercent: you’ll be more connected to the complicated history of Sevastopol (told through the computer and audio logs of its residents) than you ever will be with the main characters of the game.\n\nThe best way I can summarize this game is that it captures everything about the original Alien movie *except* a cast of great characters and a sense of conclusion.  This is a game that only will ever truly seem to stop until you simply stop playing it.  This game is indeed a triumph for the Alien franchise
votesHelpful: but lacks the storytelling and sense of climax and closure the first Alien movie us.  It’s not a game you can replay to get served the same enjoyable meal again; it’s more like to experience the same mental high that will satisfy
votesTotal: but ultimately fade away and leave you burnt out until the next time you are ready to experience the terror of the Alien once more."

reviewText:
There are a TON of positive reviews for this game.  Pay close attention to those  not the 300 or so negative ones. That said I think maybe the gamers that rated this game negatively just might not really care for this kind of game play. Many accuse this game of padding. Padding ?  who cares any fan of  the Alien(s) movies will love this game  and the so called padding iw WHY. unlike other movie franchise games This one lets you explore teh things you want to explore as opposed leading you by the nose and slapping your face with invisible walls.   That, this games does not. Now if you are not a Alien fan , or you can't stand slow pacing games  then maybe this game is not for you. I honestly think any and every PC gamer should own this game myself. Here's my break down.

The Good:

Gorgeous enviroments that make you feel like you are really in an Alien movie.
A stealth system that actually works realisticly.
Great story.
Great exploration into a reknowned franchise.
All aroud pretty graphics that  don't slug chug your PC.
Awesome AI.

The Bad

Unstopable alien, It would have been nice if a few more weapons scared off the alien other than just the flame thrower.
Less than stellar lip syncing.  It's not the worse lip sync job I've seen, but it could have been better.
Pooing your pants.


That said I give this game a excited 95%.  it's also worth a few replays with the AI. When you think you know what teh alien will do it some time surprises you.

reviewText:
This is the game that every Alien fan has dreamed of. It is immersive, terrifying and the Alien AI is simply great. You never know when it hits because it's so unpredictable. The sound and the setting of the game is based on the first Alien movie from 1979. There is alot to discover. I stopped and looked very carefully at EVERYTHING and I was so fascinated from all the details. Upholstered walls, clunky computers and old technology, the original and chilling soundtrack from the movie + there are tons of logbooks and audiofiles for you to read or listen to (even from the Nostromo-Crew, how AWSOME is that??). This is a very immersive game so I would recommend playing it with a stereo headset for full experience.

If you are an Alien Fan you should definitely get this game. If you are not an Alien Fan you should still get this game!
But if you liked Alien Colonial Marines and you are the type of player who needs to rush through everything this is probably not the game for you.

Also uber-elitist-hardcore-alien-fans who still are not pleased with this game and can't appreciate it should simply ♥♥♥♥ off.

reviewText:
Wow, so this is a Survival horror game.  I don't know what I have been playing in the past but this is a new level of genuine fear.

All I ask of people who want to experience fear on a new level is don your grannies incontenance pads and play the 'Crew Expendable' bonus game on HARD setting and prepare to play open mouthed and adrenaline pumped and probably a little damp!

I died, I died so many times, each a terrifying body blow to my senses.  I hid, I ran, I crawled and as last resort I tried to burn that sleek big ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but in the end I just died, horribly in a pool of my own sweat and ♥♥♥♥!
I wasn't dissapointed though, it would be laughable if the 'perfect killing machine' was brought down by a space jockey with a windproof lighter and manly 70's beard.

As for the actual single player campaign, so far so good, I am still playing it in 'short controlled bursts' for the sake of my abused adrenal system and nerves of which are a shattered mess.

So as so aptly put by Ash when asked 'There's gotta be a way of killing it, How? How do we do it?'


YOU CAN'T!

reviewText: This game took it's inspiration from the first Alien movie(1979); certain cinematics, enviroment(rooms, facilities,utilities, even the computers look alike and of course we get to see some of the equipment like movement detector). For a fan of the Alien series it's very enjoyable! Facing single alien is quite challenging at times. You are given mutliple choices how to avoid him, from making contraptions from the items you craft to initialising secondary systems and of course you can keep low profile and hide wherever it's possible(some places let us hide in them like lockers or we can go through vants which seems to be very useful). It's not a game where you just have to go forward, you need to come back to certain locations with a keycode to unlock them, find data in the computers or search for a passcode and sometimes you need a special tool to open certain doors. So far so good, it is as they say a survival game and fortunately alien here is something to be feared which adds a lot to the game since you do whatever you can to avoid confrontation.

reviewText:
Ok, basics first.

Graphics are great, sound is very engaging, keeps you guessing at all times. But what gets me the most is the genuine feel that your being hunted by an apex predator. It reacts to sounds, movement even your breathing.
You don't get some impressive arsenal of weapons, instead what you get is the most impressive way to test your survival skills. Use a noise distraction? Perhaps a Molotov cocktail to scare it away? Hide....hold your breath and wait for the chance to sneak by? Scavange for supplies.
Not only is the Alien about but like in real life peoples primal instinct to survive sets in. People will attack you for your gear, or simply because they think you'll take their's. Lure the Alien in and let it take them out perhaps? Sooooo many options.

I find often while I 'lurk' about I get so absorbed into this game that the second something surprises me I hit the wrong keys, freeze up, panic, even jump in my seat! THIS is what makes the game so much fun!

I haven't finished it yet but the Story thus far would make an AMAZING film addition to the Aliens Trilogy. One that would bring it back to the Alien and Aliens roots before the movies went all gun totting on us. (Yes I remember the gun totting Marines in Aliens) Out numbered, scared, limited ammo, not knowing when it will show up.

In the end I highly recommend this to anyone whose a fan of the Aliens Trilogy. There have been some bad movies and even worse games but THIS game, sets itself apart. You WILL jump, you WILL sweat, you WILL let out a quick inhale or scream maybe. Most importantly, you WILL be glad you bought it.

Cheers!

reviewText:
Alright then, we have another Alien game right here. First off i'd like to say I had my doubts about this one after the colonial marines dissapointment and waiting so long for it to come out. However, in this instance i'm happy to report that Isolation is 10x better than any other Alien game to date so far in my opinion. They've done a real good job so far in the minor time i've been playing, best of all, it makes want to play more which Colonial didn't.

The main point of the atmosphere is to inspire fear and terror in the shadows and sounds, i'd say they've achieved that brilliantly here. As you move through the levels, the distant sounds and lighting effects create a trapped feeling and maybe that something is truely lurking around every corner. And the level design is quite detailed as well increasing the immersion effect dramatically.

Add on the use of survival skills and items you need to collect along with the revolver and such, it's become a nice package to play. A simple but effective system for the player to take control of and use to their own play styles, stealth or all out attack but personally i'd recommend stealth in this one.

Overall then, i'd say this is the Alien game we'd been waiting for since Alien Vs Predator all those years ago. And finally they've delivered it to us in a brilliant way, love it and will continue to play. :)

reviewText:
An absolutely fantastic experience, I myself am not a fan of horror or stealth games but I love sci-fi and the alien universe, so this was a must pick up for me.

The graphics are absolutely stunning, there is so much attention to detail its hard to take it all in at times and I spent the first part of the game just examining every little part of the place. The particle effects that puff when every door opens, the incredible lighting and the particles even had shadows on them, I cannot fault the aesthetics of the game which perfectly recreate and expand upon the films universe. I only ever encountered a few minor visual glitches and some I only picked up on as I am a level designer myself, like a few visible seams and clipping issues but they were so minor and rare its barely worth noting.

The atmosphere is incredible, you never feel safe ever, even in your hiding spaces you can be caught, the sound design truly helps with this. The foley work and sound effects throughout the entire game are just incredible, every last creak and groan of air ducts really adds to the unease and tension. That's not to say you never get a break, cooldown chapters are interspersed to stop it becoming too stressful, particularly after very tense missions, where you dont have too much danger to deal with. The sound also plays just as important a role as your motion tracker in letting you know where enemies are and when the alien is in the vents.

The music again is great and the dynamic score can actually aid you as it gets steadily more dramatic as you get closer to being detected. It also helps keep the tension up during the dramatic parts and to spur you on when you are caught and have to either run away or defend yourself.

The game tutorialises each new enemy really well, they each tend to get their own dedicated chapter which starts of pretty hard until you learn how to avoid each enemy type. You also get new tools along the way and with regards to the backtracking I didnt have any problems as different paths are open or closed, there are different enemies and with your new tools you can find different ways around. There are multiple solutions for getting through the rooms and it was interesting to see the completely different approaches my friends took when playing the game.

Storywise it was pretty good with a few plot twists and turns, some predictable, some not, i thought the ending was ok but not as great as it could have been.

Overall, 10 out of 10 from me, a must play for sci-fi and Alien fans, stunning locations and some fantastic set pieces, with incredible sound design, cannot recommend enough, fantastic.

reviewText:
Finally a game that justifies the Alien series, it really manages to capture the horror of being hunted by something you can't fight. To keep this review short:

The good:
-The game is styled to the way they saw the future when making the first Alien movie, which means computers are massive and nothing really feels modern, even though it takes place in space
-The alien is unpredictable, the AI of the Xeno is fantastic besides some minor things. Like one time it ran past me while i was in the middle of his path, now don't think you can just run around, because there isn't much you can do when he sees you.
-Ammo is hard to get, there are guns which can only kill people and the androids, not aliens. Each shot has to be justified as you can't allow to waste a lot of ammo
-You're hunted, this game does this better than anything I've ever played. Hiding in a closet while hearing humans being brutally murdered one by one. You will die a lot in this game, but it always feels like it was your mistake
-Graphics are great, the lightning especially is really well done

The bad:
-The interactions feel robotic, it's stupid that there are about 4 seconds in between exiting a computer and being able to walk. Anyone can see and kill you during this period. Does capture the horror element quite well, but it just feels unnecessary
-Not being able to jump over small obstacles, i get the horror element, but do i really need to be stuck to the ground if i can take a shortcut over that small barrier?
-Story isn't all that interesting, i didn't find any character to be interesting

Definitely a game I'd recommend, get some surround headphones and this game won't be like anything you've ever played.

reviewText:
This game is a (terrifying) love letter to any person who prefers the original Alien movie to its also fantastic sequel. Even players who don't usually like horror games will feel compelled to go on and explore the picture-perfect recreation of the dark, low-high-tech sci-fi vision of the 1979's movie, filled with CRT screens, mechanical computers and steam vents.

This is not a shooter, so be prepared to hide, crouch through vents, and peer in horror at your motion detector as the beeping green blip comes closer and closer to you while you try to hold your breath and not make a noise.

The game is difficult, occasionally unfair, and has a checkpoint save system that reminds me of Dark Souls' bonfires. It all works great to build an incredible level of tension and fear, but it will also be frustrating to players who don't want to try something different to modern straightforward shooters with quicksave systems.

Technically, the game is a wonder. Graphics are the best I've ever seen, and they feel very well optimized for PC. Sound is even better. Every mechanical noise will bring you back to the original movie, and the music feels dynamic and opressive, including some cues from the original movie soundtrack. The surround audio is also brilliant, and it's just as useful as your motion detector when trying to guess where the creature is.

I can't recommend this game highly enough for fans of the first Alien movie, OR fans of horror games. For everyone else, it will probably not be their cup of tea.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The moment I started the game, it started making me feel as though I were in a real situation.  This game is highly immersive.  The Environments made me feel as though I became a part of the Alien universe.  If you're a fan of horror games, if you're a fan of the Alien movie series, or both, this game is amazing.  Even if you're not a fan of either, if you want a truely immersive experience, play this game.  I haven't felt this since my first run through of dead space, when I thought to myself, this is what an Alien game should be"\n\nThey've finally made it.  I hope I survive."
